dataObject.dc:description: Photo credit: Elizabeth Norton

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Nyssodesmus python is of the Kingdom Animalia; Phylum Arthropoda; Class Diplopoda; Order Polydesmidae; Family Platyrhacidae . It is a large, terrestrial, tropical forest millipede (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Members of this species are found in Central America, on both slopes of Costa Rica (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995). Adults are whitish brown with two dark longitudinal stripes along their backs and have 20 body segments (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Being detritivores, their diet consists mainly of rotting wood so they are important decomposers in forest ecosystems (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Copulation between males and females is venter to venter and the sperm is stored inside the female until the time of oviposition (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Therefore, if females mate with multiple males before this occurs, sperm from different males will compete to fertilize the clutch of eggs. In order to ensure the success of their own sperm, males of this species will ride atop their female partner for up to 5 days to stop them from mating with other males (Borrell, B.J. 2004). When the partners encounter a potential mate, the male forces the females body to close over her genital openings, making copulation impossible (Heisler, I. L. 1983). N. python defense mechanisms consist of the protection of their hard, calcified exoskeleton, the ability to roll into a spiral in response to disturbance, and the production of a toxic liquid containing cyanide that they can project up to 30 cm (Loomis, H.G. 1968).

Little is known about the natural history of tropical millipedes (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description:
Predation

Their morphological and chemical defenses deter most potential predators, which are mostly avian (Borrell, B.J. 2004). Males are most at risk of predation by birds while they ride atop their mates for several days after copulation (Borrell, B.J. 2004). Most likely sources of adult mortality are parasitism, desiccation, and traumatic injury especially during vulnerable molting periods (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description:
Individuals of this species are diurnal, terrestrial, and dispersed rather than aggregated (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995). Like most millipedes in their order, they are blind (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995).

Defense

Like almost all millipedes, N. python produces toxic chemicals to use in defense against predators (Heisler, I. L. 1983). When disturbed they roll into a spiral/ball, tucking their vulnerable head segment within it’s rolled body (Loomis, H.G. 1968). This is an adaptive feature that has evolved independently in many polydesmoid families (Loomis, H.G. 1968). Millipedes of this order produce a liquid containing hydrogen cyanide and benzaldehyde in two-chambered glands in their hindgut, and can forcibly spray it up to 30 cm (Loomis, H.G. 1968).

Millipedes are also protected by large and rigid exoskeleton. Calcified exoskeleton of N. python exhibits distinct mechanical advantages over other insect cuticles (Borrell, B.J. 2004). It plays a crucial role in protection against predation but also in resisting large forces developed during burrowing locomotion (Borrell, B.J. 2004). Bulkiness of their exoskeleton has been minimized through the deposition of calcium salts, which is not characteristic of all millipedes (Borrell, B.J. 2004).

Mating interaction

The most distinctive behavioral aspect of N. python is the riding of females by males after copulation; year round they are mostly hound in heterosexual pairs with the male standing on the female’s dorsum (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Males ride females up to 5 days and possibly longer, and solitary females are uncommon, rarely unescorted for more than 24 hrs (Heisler, I. L. 1983). The most selective force driving the evolution of mate guarding behavior is probably sexual selection on males in the form of sperm competition (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995). Since females remain receptive for prolonged periods of time they will mate with many males, but since sperm isn’t used until immediately before oviposition in millipedes, multiple matings by females leads to competition among the sperm from different males for fertilization of a single clutch of eggs (Adolph, S.C. and Geber, M.A. 1995). When a sexual competitor is present, the male riding on top of the female will flex the anterior segments of its body to force a female’s head and anterior segments over her genital openings, cutting off sexual access for the competitor (Heisler, I. L. 1983). This is possible because the male millipedes of this species are significantly stronger than the females (Borrell, B.J. 2004). However, during this mate-guarding it is unknown if the riding male continues to mate with that same female (Borrell, B.J. 2004). Post-copulatory riding has not been found in other species and probably evolved due to a combination of exceptionally high population density and relatively non-seasonal breeding which make extended receptivity and multiple mating by females more likely (Adolph, S.C. and Geber, M.A. 1995).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation
dataObject.dc:description:
N. python are important as decomposers for the ecosystems in which they live (Heisler, I. L. 1983). They also have an important role in mineral cycle since exoskeletons contain large quantities of calcium salts in addition to chiton, unlike most other land arthropods (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

No found negative or positive affects on or economic benefits for humans.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: This species occurs in lowland forests of the eastern and western slopes of Costa Rica (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995). Their exact range unknown, but they are abundant at La Selva in Costa Rica, there found almost exclusively in the plant Heliconia imbricate in old cacao groves where understory is uncut (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Growth
dataObject.dc:description:
Eggs hatch revealing 7-segmented juveniles that then pass through a series of juvenile stadia by molting in chambers in soil (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

Juveniles resemble adults in shape but are smaller, not pigmented, and have fewer segments (Heisler, I. L. 1983). With each molt new segments appear and legs appear on previously apodous segments (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

Newly molted adults are soft and not pigmented – full pigmentation (dull whitish yellow with two dark brown longitudinal stripes extending along sloping margins of the back) and calcification of exoskeleton takes a month (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Adult individuals range in body mass from 2 to 7 g (Borrell, B.J. 2004). They have 20 body segments, 19 of which have horizontally oriented keels, resembling overlong, large isopods (Heisler, I. L. 1983). On the males, the first pair of legs on 7th segment is modified into small curved gonopods for sperm transfer (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

Sexually dimorphic – Females are larger: 70-100 mm in length and 13-15 mm greatest width, males are smaller: 65-90 mm long and 12.5-14.5 mm wide (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: They live mostly in dank, humid habitats, such as in rotten logs, among leaf litter, in the soil, under stones, in caves, and in loose tree bark (Loomis, H.G. 1968). N. python are among the most powerful of the burrowing millipedes; they wedge their way through compact soil and build chambers in the soil to molt in and to lay eggs in (Borrell, B.J. 2004).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy
dataObject.dc:description: Life span is unknown but is probably more than a year and may be as much as several years (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: In females, the external genital openings (vulvae) are located ventrally in the connective membrane between the 2nd and 3rd segments (Heisler, I. L. 1983). In males the spermatic ducts open on or near coxae of 2nd pair of legs (Heisler, I. L. 1983). The male rolls anterior portion of body to bring his gonopods in contact with the openings and transfer sperm into them for venter-to-venter copulation (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Sperm transferred by series of thrusts and is then stored in special receptacles until the time of oviposition (Heisler, I. L. 1983). Eggs are laid in small cavities in soil often constructed from frass; males are not known to contribute to nest construction or guarding (Adolph SC and Geber MA. 1995).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TrophicStrategy
dataObject.dc:description: N. python are detritivores, feeding largely upon rotting wood (Heisler, I. L. 1983). They possess a diversified gut flora to release nutrients and reduce toxins in ingested plant material (Heisler, I. L. 1983).

taxon.reference: Bergman, B., Johansson, C., and E. Soderback. (1992). The Nostoc-Gunnera Symbiosis. New Phytologist. 122:379-400
Gargiullo, M. B., Magnuson, B., and L. Kimball. (2008). A Field Guide to Plants of Costa Rica. Oxford, UK: Oxford University Press.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Gunnera insignis (Poor man’s umbrella) is a highland species (800 – 2600 m) found in mountain ranges from Nicaragua down to Colombia (Gargiullo 2008; Zuchowski 2007). It is found in wet forests, frequently in disturbed and open areas or exposed ridgelines (Gargiullo 2008; Zuchowski 2007). G. insignis ability to grow in poor soil is attributed to its symbiotic relationship with the cyanobacteria Nostoc punctiforme which fix nitrogen for the plant. In return, G. insignis provides nutrients for the bacteria (Gargiullo 2008; Zuchowski 2007). G. insignis is a herbaceous plant in which the stem can grow up to 30 cm tall. The petioles can be up to 2.5 m long and can sometimes be red. The leaves can grow up to 2 m wide and grow in a rosette arrangement. These large umbrella-like leaves are toothed, palmately lobed, with 5 main veins dividing the leaf. The veins are occasionally red. The plant produces a conical red inflorescence that can grow 1 m long (Gargiullo 2008; Zuchowski 2007). The flowers are hermaphroditic, but can occasionally be unisexual. They do not have bracts or petals (Ronse de Craene and Wanntorp 2006). These produce many small (0.2 cm long) red or orange single-seeded fruits (Gargiullo 2008; Zuchowski 2007). The plant is wind pollinated. Another much smaller species in the genus, Gunnera talamancana, has been shown to hybridize with G. insignis (Palkovic 1978). G. talamancana is found in Costa Rica and Panama. This hybridization does not occur frequently though, due to the fact that their typical habitat of disturbed areas is usually small and liable to change (Palkovic 1978).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description:
Ecological Relationship with Nostoc punctiforme

Gunnera insignis has a symbiotic relationship with the cyanobacteria Nostoc punctiforme (Gargiullo 2008). It has been found that the parent plant does not supply each seed with bacteria, so it is likely the seed is infected when germinating (Bergman et al. 1992). This can easily happen because Nostoc is common in humid soils, a typical habitat for G. insignis. It is also hypothesized that N. punctiforme may reach the seedling by water or wind. The bacteria then infest special mucus covered glands in the stems of G. insignis and begin to differentiate into heterocysts, which are the actual nitrogen-fixing cells. It is unknown what signals the being of this differentiation (Bergman et al. 1992).

taxon.reference: BirdLife International. 2013. Species factsheet: Megaceryle torquata. http://www.birdlife.org.
Brush, T. 2009. Ringed Kingfisher (Megaceryle torquata), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/718.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
The Ringed Kingfisher (Megaceryle torquata, formerly Ceryle torquata) is the largest Kingfisher in the Americas (Henderson 2010). They can grow up to 41 cm and weigh up to 290g (Stiles and Skutch 1989). This species is sexually dimorphic in coloration. Males have a slate grey coloration above, a rufous breast, and a white collar in between (Fogden 2005). Additionally, they have white spots in front of and behind the eyes (Stiles and Skutch 1989). They also have a bushy crest that is finely streaked with black and wing and tail feathers that are black, spotted and barred with white, and broadly edged with blue and grey (Stiles and Skutch 1989). Females look similar, however the grey extends to the top of the breast and is separated from the rufous breast by a second white band (Fogden 2005). Juveniles resemble females but the breast is paler and the white band on the chest is indistinct or absent (Brush 2009).

Ringed Kingfishers are found up to 900m in elevation from Southern Texas to Tierra del Fuego and in the Lower Antilles (Stiles and Skutch 1989). The Ringed Kingfisher has a large range, the population is large and increasing, so the species is considered of Least Concern by BirdLife International (2013).

These kingfishers hunt in both fresh and salt water along rivers, lakes and estuaries (Fogden 2005). The North American populations are non-migratory (Brush 2009). They dive from higher perches than many other kingfisher species and return immediately to their perch after catching prey (Fogden 2005). Unlike other kingfisher species, the Ringed Kingfisher does not hover over the water while hunting (Henderson 2010). They feed almost exclusively on fish, but occasionally eat crabs and other crustaceans (Brush 2009).

They make burrows in banks with an unlined chamber at the end (Stiles and Skutch 1989). Both sexes participate in constructing the nest (Brush 2009). The horizontal tunnel is 15 centimeters (6 inches) high, 10 centimeters (4 inches) wide, and 1.2 to 1.8 meters (6 to 8 feet) deep (Henderson 2010). In Costa Rica, Ringed Kingfishers nest from January to March (Henderson 2010). Females lay 3 to 5 eggs per season (Stiles and Skutch 1989). Chicks are feathered after 24 days and leave the nest 35-38 days after hatching (Brush 2009). They are solitary except while breeding; both males and females defend the territory during the breeding season (Brush 2009).

Ringed Kingfishers are very vocal. They utter a loud “klek-klek-klek” rattling alarm call when disturbed (Henderson 2010). A single, loud “klek” is used as contact call; pair members alternate low calls while raising and lowering the tail (Stiles and Skutch 1989).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: The Volcano Hummingbird is endemic to the Central Cordillera in Costa Rica, and to the Talamanca Cordilleras of Costa Rica and western Panama. It occupies mountaintops from 1800 meters to the highest peaks, and descends as low as 1200 meters in the non-breeding season (Stiles & Skutch 1989). Individuals have a green back but exhibit clear sexual dimorphism that varies by region: males are distinguished by bright gorget color and the amount of buffy and black below the tail, which increase with latitude (Stiles & Skutch 1989). In contrast, females lack a colored gorget, have a white breast, and are slightly larger than males (Henderson 2002); average female weight is 2.8 g while average male weight is 2.5 grams (Stiles & Skutch 198), though both are approximately 7.5 centimeters in length (Garrigues & Dean 2007). Evolutionarily, mountaintops exist as genetic islands of suitable habitat, which contribute to regional variation within the species (Ditto & Frey 2007, Garrigues & Dean 2007). At these high elevations, the Volcano Hummingbird prefers to forage in montane forest and forest edges (including páramo), overgrown open areas, and gardens (Henderson 2002). Stiles and Skutch (1989) also note a preference for secondary growth resulting from volcanic eruptions, landslides, or human disturbance. Volcano hummingbirds are nectar-feeding trapliners, meaning they visit a regular circuit of the same flowers to forage (Gill 1988). Preferred nectar sources are a variety of small, often insect-pollinated flowers including Fuchsia, Salvia, Bomarea, foxglove (Digitalis), Indian paintbrush (Castilleja), blueberry (Vaccinium) and blackberry (Rubus), and Miconia (Henderson 2002). They will also filch nectar from tubular flowers in the territory of larger hummingbirds (Hilty 1994; Fogden & Fogden 2005). The Volcano Hummingbird enters torpor at night, a period when body temperature is lowered to near ambient to conserve energy (Bucher & Chappell 1997), and has a much faster metabolism than larger species (Wolf et al. 1975); a nesting female should visit about 2700 flowers per day to account for metabolic and foraging energy costs (Hainsworth & Wolf 1972). Stiles & Skutch (1989) observe that during the breeding season (August-February), female Volcano Hummingbirds construct compact cup nests decorated with moss and lichen on the outermost branches of trees and shrubs or dangling from overhanging banks facing south or east. Males are very territorial of desirable perches and surrounding foraging area and defend them with diving displays that include loud calls and wing snapping (Fogden & Fogden 2005; Clark et al. 2011). As with other high elevation species, the Volcano Hummingbird is sensitive to climate change that pushes suitable habitats further up mountaintops (Lawler et al. 2009).

taxon.reference: Andrews, R. M. 1983. Norops polylepis. In D. H. Janzen (Ed.), Costa Rican Natural History (pp. 409-410). Chicago, IL: The University of Chicago Press.

Leenders, T. 2001. Norops polylepis. Amphibians and Reptiles of Costa Rica (pp. 187-188). Miami, FL: The Zona Tropical Publication.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description:
N. polylepis is highly territorial, but, males and females differ in their reasons for being territorial. Males defend large areas against intrusion by other males: territory size can be as big as 65 sq m but it is an average of 30 sq m. During territorial interactions the dewlap is extended repeatedly and the head and body are bobbed up and down in patterns of typical species. Displays are used to advertise the presence of a resident male, if an intruder enters the resident males territory the male will display and if the intruder does not leave it may escalate to aggressive behavior (chasing and biting). The resident male is usually successful at driving away the intruder (Andrews, 1983).

The territory of one adult male includes the territories of 1-3 adult females, therefore, the territorial behavior is attributed to the maintenance of exclusive access to females. A female's territory size is about 7 sq m and is used entirely for feeding purposes. Juveniles are also territorial but their territories do not overlap with others (Leenders, 2001).

N. polylepis has structural perching; individuals typically perch 3 m above the ground but males spend more than half of their day perching on higher branches. This is because higher perches are better vantage points for spotting and interacting with other males. But when males are feeding or courting females they perch lower to the ground. Females spend 90% of their active day scanning the surroundings for food in low perches while males spend 50% of their active day interacting with other males on higher perches (Andrews, 1983). However, it has also been found that individuals with the presence of ecdysis perch higher than average, this is particularly notorious for juveniles (Barquero & Arguedas, 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Norops polylepis ranges from low to middle elevations in the rainforests of southwestern Costa Rica and adjacent pastures (Andrews, 1983). It is exclusive to Golfo Dulce area in southwest Costa Rica (Leenders, 2001).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology
dataObject.dc:description:
N. polylepis is small and arboreal, they are usually found perching on understory vegetation up to 3 m above the ground in shaded habitats (Andrews, 1983). It is endemic to southwestern Costa Rica and it is the most commonly encountered of the seven species of Norops reported in this area. This may be because other Norops live high in the forest canopy and have low population densities. They have been recorded in low and middle elevation rainforests (Andrews, 1983). It has also been recorded in premontane wet forests, for example, Corcovado National Park. According to a study N. polylepis is more abundant along edges of the forest during the end of the dry season and appears to be more abundant in the interior forest after the onset of the wet season (Schlaepfer, 2001). It has been speculated that they may migrate to the edges of forests during the dry season because this season isn't the peak of reproduction, therefore, they are less territorial. Future studies may show that species exploit edge or interior habitats depending on time of day, weather conditions, seasons, or life stage.

The bulk of the N. polylepis diet consists of soft-bodied insects such as larvae of lepidopterans, crickets and other orthopterans, and cockroaches. The prey is relatively large: more than 50% of items are 5 mm or more in length (Andrews, 1983). They feed about once every hour; individuals leave their perches to go catch prey. N. polylepis relies on prey movement to locate prey. They perch head downward on tree trunks and visually search for prey, usually in the leaf litter. When they locate movement from an object of prey, they run from their perch and try to catch it (Andrews, 1983).

Due to their small size and exposed perches, N. polylepis is susceptible to a diversity of predators. The most common predators include motmots and trogons, many species of snakes, especially the vine snake, also, two sympatric lizard, Norops capito and Corytophanes cristatus. As juveniles it has been found that large invertebrates, such as mantids and predaceous katydids, can be predators (Andrews, 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy
dataObject.dc:description: Most individuals do not live for more than one year (Andrews, 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: Norops polylepis is sexually dimorphic in body size: males reach a maximum snout-vent length of 52 mm, and females reach a maximum of 48 mm. Males have a solid orange throat fan or dewlap. The body color is usually a solid or blotchy brown, but some females have a distinct middorsal white stripe or series of diamond-shaped figures (Andrews, 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: N. polylepis reproduction is correlated with rainfall. Although females lay eggs year round, the proportion of females with oviducal eggs is less during the dry season. This also correlates with behavioral observations that showed an increase in courtship and copulation at the onset of the wet season (May-June). A single leathery-shelled egg is laid every week in the wet season, and approximately every two weeks in the dry season (Leenders, 2001). There is a 50-day incubation period. The newly hatched N. polylepis has a snout length of 19 mm. They grow rapidly and in about three to four months they become sexually mature, with a snout length of 39 mm (Andrews, 1983).
Male N.polylepis displaying dewlap. Picture taken in Corcovado National Park, Costa Rica.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Enterolobium cyclocarpum, called elephant ear or Guanacaste tree, is found from Mexico to northern South America and the Antilles (Zuchowski 2007). In Costa Rica, it is conspicuous in the canopy of deciduous and semi-deciduous lowland forests up to 1,300 m (Janzen 1983, Zuchowski 2007). This towering species dominates pastures and grasslands of the Pacific slopes of Panama and Costa Rica (Condit et al. 2011), especially the seasonally dry Guanacaste region, named after the tree.

Guanacaste trees have broad crowns, sometimes wider than tall. Leaves are alternate and bipinnate, with small dish-like glands on the leaf raquis between pairs of leaflets. Leaflets are narrow, oblong, and feathery (Condit et al. 2011). In the Guanacaste region, entire leaf crops can be destroyed by the moth Coenipita bibitrix in July (Janzen 1983). Bark is gray and relatively smooth, with fine vertical furrows (Gentry 1993). Although the heartwood is fungus-resistant, fallen branches and logs readily decompose. Wounded trees seal gashes with water-soluble gum (Janzen 1983). Flowers—small white balls of stamens produced from January to May—are visited by small moths and beetles.

Trees yield dark reddish-brown indehiscent ear-shaped pods, which take one year to mature. Pods, approximately 12 cm in diameter, hold about 14 seeds from 1.5 to 2 cm long (Zuchowski 2007). Seeds contain insecticidal amino acid (Rehr et al. 1973) and are rich in protein and starches (Jiménez-Hernández et al. 2011). In Costa Rica, these defenses prove effective against bruchid beetles and other insects that commonly predate legume seeds (Janzen 1983). Green seeds contain saponins (Janzen 1983), plant compounds that deter herbivory or predation (Potter and Kimmerer 1989, Hoagland et al. 1996, Osbourn 1996). Nonetheless, Amazona parrots are vigorous seed predators (Zuchowski 2007). To germinate, the seed coats must be punctured, such as during digestion or soil abrasion (Janzen 1983). In Costa Rica, Liomys salvini, the spiny pocket mouse, collects seeds from dung or fallen pods. The mice hoard seeds, later nicking the seed coats to encourage germination and feeding on the seedlings, which are less toxic (Janzen 1982, Zuchoski 2007). Janzen (1982) posits that L. salvini predation ensures that guanacaste cannot reproduce in forests occupied by the mice.

Janzen and Martin (1982) suggest that Guanacaste seeds were once dispersed by Pleistocene megafauna; seeds today are dispersed mostly by the modern day equivalents, cattle and horses. Where these animals are absent, germination is usually unsuccessful, and new saplings are rare in forested areas (Condit et al. 2011). In pastures, trees receive significantly less pollen and produce fewer seeds per fruit than in continuous forest. Moreover, saplings are less viable in pastures than in forests (Rocha and Aguilar 2001). Trampling, fire, competition with grasses, and desiccation from heat keeps seed reproduction low (Janzen 1983).

Throughout Central and South America, Guanacaste trees are planted for myriad uses. Saponins in the bark and pods make them effective soap substitutes. The fungus-resistant hardwood is used for furniture, fence posts, and firewood. The distinctive spotted seeds are used in jewelry. The sap is collected to treat bronchitis, and the green fruits, to alleviate diarrhea (Zochoski 2007).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Aratus pisonii, commonly known as the Mangrove Tree Crab, is a member of the Grapsidae family (monotypic genus) and is found in the edges of mangrove forests from eastern Florida to northern Brazil on the Atlantic coast and from Nicaragua to Perú on the Pacific coast (Rathbun 1918, Chace and Hobbs 1969 [as cited in Díaz and Conde 1989]). The adults are arboreal and live in the supralittoral zone of the roots, branches, and canopy of mangroves, primarily Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans (Díaz and Conde 1989, Simberloff 1983). They return to the water to drink, to breed, and as a potential escape from predators (Díaz and Conde 1989). The males of this species have a larger carapace width than the females, possibly due to a larger allocation of energy going towards reproduction in the females. Females also tend to have a longer time between molts, a trend that is especially notable in ovigerous females (Díaz and Conde 1989). Multiple studies have found a higher abundance of females compared to males (Díaz and Conde 1989, Conde et. al. 2000). Their diet is primarily composed of mangrove leaves although they have been known to eat filamentous algae, large insects and fish as well (Simberloff 1983, Díaz and Conde 1989). Predation by birds and other crabs such as Goniopsis cruentata have been documented but are not considered to have a large effect on A. pisonii mortality. Occasionally, the crabs will jump into the water in order to escape a predator, often leading to predation by fish (Díaz and Conde 1989). Females lay eggs throughout the year with the majority of females in their last trimester occurring in the rainy season. There is a positive correlation between female carapace width and number of eggs produced with the mean number of eggs per female equaling 11,577 (Díaz and Conde 1989). In Jamaica, the breeding patterns seem to be correlated with lunar cycles. This is thought to be because a high tide will prevent larval stranding (Warner 1967 as cited in Díaz and Conde 1989). In the edges of mangrove forests, larval stranding is not an issue due to the consistently high water level. For this reason, lunar cycles do not seem to have an effect on breeding patterns in these habitats. For individuals of A. pisonii that inhabit the interior of mangrove forests, there is a possible migration to the forest edge for the purpose of breeding, although this has not been verified. Overall, A. pisonii is a sedentary species and has not been shown to migrate (Díaz and Conde 1989). The larva of A. pisonii undergoes 5 aquatic stages: 4 zoeal stages and one megalopal stage, although one study found cases where one or even two of the zoael stages were suppressed (Cuesta et al. 2006, Díaz and Bevilacqua 1987). Each zoeal stage lasts between 4-6 days and the megalopal stage duration has not been determined (Cuesta et. al. 2006).

Smilanich, A. M., and Dyer, L. A. 2012. Effects of banana plantation pesticides on the immune response of lepidopteran larvae and their parasitoid natural enemies. Insects 3(3): 616-628.
Stevens, M., Hardman, C., and Stubbins, C. 2008. Conspicuousness, not eye mimicry, makes “eyespots” effective antipredator signals. Behavioral Ecology 19(3): 525-531.

Young, A. and Muyshondt, A. 1985. Notes on Caligo memnon Felder and Caligo atreus Kollar (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Brassolinae) in Costa Rica and El Salvador. Journal of Research on the Lepidoptera 24(2): 154-175.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: This large owl butterfly ranges from Mexico to Columbia from sea level to 1400 meters elevation (DeVries 1983). It is distinguished from similar species by its size (13cm wingspan) and blue-gray dorsal wings with cream-colored patch on forewing. Its ventral wing surface is brown and tan with many lines and two large eye spots. Eggs are laid in small clusters and caterpillars feed on the underside of large-leaved monocots in the Order Zingiberales, including the non-native banana (Musa acuminata: Musaceae). C. memnon is crepuscular, resting for most of the day, though adults are sometimes seen feeding during the day on their diet of rotting fruit and sap flows. Large eye spots on wings may resemble predator eyes, but the main anti-predatory behavior is likely crypsis with eye spots acting as targets for predators, allowing the butterfly time to escape (Stevens et al. 2008).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description: Plants of the genera Musa (Musaceae) and Heliconia (Heliconiaceae) are fed on by the larvae of this butterfly (DeVries 1987; Smilanich & Dyer 2012; Young & Muyshondt 1985). C. memnon eggs have aso been found on plants in Cannaceae and Marantaceae (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Musaceae, Heliconiaceae, Cannaceae, and Marantaceae are all in the Order Zingiberales. It is possible that the introduction of large monocultures of bananas (Musa) to the Neotropics has significantly affected the abundance and distribution of C. memnon (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Use of insecticides on banana plantations has lowered the populations of parasitoid wasps from the family Trichogrammatidae, the natural predators of C. memnon (DeVries 1987; Smilanich & Dyer 2012). These tiny wasps cling to the anal margin of the hindwing of male and famale Caligo and can be transferred during mating (DeVries 1987). As the female lays her eggs, the wasp leaves the butterfly and parasitizes the eggs (DeVries 1987). Heavy infestations of mites can be found on the proboscis of adult C. memnon most commonly in dry-forest habitats (DeVries 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description: Female C. memnon lay eggs in groups of three to eight in a line along the border or underside of leaves, often on the midrib (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Eggs are laid on plants in Musaceae, Heliconiaceae, Cannaceae, and Marantaceae (DeVries 1987; Smilanich & Dyer 2012; Young & Muyshondt 1985). Larvae feed gregariously in groups of twelve at earlier instars and smaller groups for later instars (Young & Muyshondt 1985). No cannibalism is exhibited by the larvae of Caligo species, even among instars of different generations (DeVries 1987). Larvae feed crepuscularly and nocturnally on the leaves of plants in the genera Musa (Musaceae) and Heliconia (Heliconiaceae) (DeVries 1987; Smilanich & Dyer 2012; Young & Muyshondt 1985). The prepupa remains motionless for at least a day before molting to the pupa (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Adult C. memnon are crepuscular with peak activity occuring between 0630 and 0800 hours (Young & Muyshondt 1985). They feed on fallen fruit, sap from wounds on trees and vines, fungi, dung, and carrion (Devries 1983; Young & Muyshondt 1985). These butterflies have no chemical defense against predation, but the ocelli on its wings have been shown to act as targets for predators to attack, allowing the butterfly to escape with only a piece of its wing missing (Stevens et al. 2008).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Caligo memnon is a Neotropical species found from Mexico to the Amazon basin in Colombia at elevations lower than 1400 meters (DeVries 1987; DeVries 1983). In Costa Rica it is common on the Pacific slope but much more rare on the Atlantic slope (DeVries 1987; DeVries 1983). It is one of the only Caligo species able to tolerate the dry season of the Guanacaste region of Costa Rica and can live in severely disturbed agricultural habitats (DeVries 1987). However, it seems to be unable to tolerate rain forest conditions (DeVries 1987; DeVries 1983). C. memnon persists throughout the year and is most common in the rainy season (DeVries 1987; DeVries 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObject.dc:description: The larvae of C. memnon go through five instar stages before the pupa (chrysalis) is formed (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Adults emerge after 20 days of the pupal stage (Young & Muyshondt 1985).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy
dataObject.dc:description: The pupa stage of C. memnon lasts for 20 days (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Adults live up to 5 weeks under laboratory conditions (DeVries 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: C. memnon eggs are spherical with vertical ribs, cream coloration, and a thin brown equatorial line (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Each of the five instars of ths species have a reddish, ventrally eversible gland anterior to the first leg pair (Young & Muyshondt 1985). This gland has been shown to function as a possible defense against ants (DeVries 1987). No odor is detectable when the gland is everted (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Mature larvae of C. memnon can reach up to 110 mm and 15 g, are light brown with brown striations and pseudospines along the dorsum, and have a forked tail (DeVries 1983). The reddish brown head capsule sports a corona of stout, clubbed horns and has a dorsal evagination (DeVries 1983). C. memnon pupae are 43 mm long, 21 mm wide, and mottled brown in coloration (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Stout bristles are distributed over the abdomen with alternating brown and yellow stripes (Young & Muyshondt 1985). The angular protrusions are present on either side of the thorax (Young & Muyshondt 1985). Adult C. memnon have forewing (FW) lengths of 68-78 mm (DeVries 1987). They are characterized by a bluish-gray hue to the uppermost portion of the hindwing with large owl-like eyespots on the underside of the hind wing, an extensive yellow flush on the FW median, dark FW margins, and small submarginal ocelli on the underside of the FW (DeVries 1987). Males of this species can also be identified by the presence of hair tufts and abdominal scent organs (DeVries 1987; Young & Muyshondt 1985).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: In courtship a male C. memnon will chase a female until she lands with wings folded (DeVries 1987). He will then hover over her before landing behind her with wings folded and fluttering alongside her with his abdomen curved to the side and claspers fully open (DeVries 1987). Several tries are usually required before genital openings meet and they become coupled facing in opposite directions (DeVries 1987). If mating is unsuccessful after several tries, the male will hover over the female and dip up and down rhythmically before the process is begun anew (DeVries 1987). In order for all the eggs of a single female to be fertilized, multiple matings are required (Young & Muyshondt 1985).

Fruit inside

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
The tea mangrove is found from Nicaragua to Colombia and is most common on the pacific coast in mangals (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2007). Some isolated groups are found on the Atlantic coasts of Nicaragua, Panama, and Colombia, but are very rare (Smith 2004). Trees grow in the intertidal zone, mostly sheltered by protected beaches or estuarine banks (Tomlinson 1986). They prefer more elevated areas and are more sensitive to soil salinity than other mangrove species, inhabiting only soils with less than 37% salt concentrations (Smith 2004, Jimenez 1984).

These mangroves have swollen buttress roots that stand above the mud in low tide, and contain lenticels that aid in aeration (Simberloff 1983). These thick roots grow in succession, new roots growing above earlier roots (Tomlinson 1986). Trees can be up to 20 meters tall, and have thick, rounded, simple, alternate fibrous leaves (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2007). The leaves may contain three sets of glands along the margin and possibly on the surface of the sepals, but are not always present. The leaf glands may be used for salt excretion, and the sepal glands as extra floral nectaries that may attract insects (Smith 2004).

The white flowers are large and showy, with 5 petals up to 6 centimeters long, and have two large, pink-green bracts, which are located below the flower (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2007). Flowering occurs from winter to early spring and fruiting peaks in late fall (October) (Tomlinson 1986). Hummingbirds and insects sometimes visit flowers, but pollination is mostly unstudied and the actual pollinators might be nocturnal (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2007).

Fruits are heavy and bulb-shaped with a large point at the bottom (Simberloff 1983). They have a hard brown outer covering (exocarp) and a red/brown fleshy interior layer (mesocarp) (Tomlinson 1986). Embryos of this species are cryptoviviparous, meaning the embryo germinates inside the seed while it is still attached to the three. The embryo swells, breaking the seed coat but does not break out of the hard fruit until later (Tomlinson 1986). Fruits are dispersed by falling into the water, pointy side down, and can float before releasing seeds. The seeds germinate rapidly after they fall, swelling after a few hours, meaning the fruits cannot float for very long or for long distances (Smith 2004). The embryos quickly produce roots out of the hard exocarp, extending into the mud of shallow water (Tomlinson, 1986).

Azteca ants have a nonobligatory association with Pelliciera. These ants protect the plant from herbivorous insects and the plant provides the ants with shelter, crevices to forage, and nectar from extra floral nectaries. The association, however, does not occur through the entire geographic range of the plant (Tomlinson 1986). These ants tend to select trees that have been damaged by storms or other insects (Smith 2004).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Leucoagaricus gongylophorus is a spongy basidiomycete fungal species in the family Agaricaceae that associates with leaf-cutter ant species in the genus Atta (Silva-Pinhati et al. 2004). The leaf-cutter ants combine leaf material, fecal matter, and saliva into a mass that L. gongylophorus uses as a substrate for growth within the ant colony (Silva et al. 2006). The leaf-cutter ants maintain the L. gongylophorus garden and the swollen tips that form on the L. gongylophorus hyphae, called gongylidia, are used as a food source by the ants (Fisher et al. 1994, Silvia et al. 2003). This relationship is a crucial aspect of both the leaf-cutter ant and the L. gongylophorus lifecycles because: (a) L. gongylophorus has lost the ability to produce spores (Stevens 1983), and has likely been cultivated asexually by leaf-cutter ants for up to 23 million years (Chapela et al. 1994); (b) without L. gongylophorus as a food source within the colony, the leaf-cutter ants would die (Fisher et al. 1996). Some studies argue that this relationship is an obligate mutualism (Fisher et al. 1996), however other studies have shown that Atta ants can survive outside of this symbiosis (Silvia et al 2003; Littledyke & Cherrett 1976; Quinlan & Cherrett 1979).

The co-evolution is likely the mechanism behind the tight leaf-cutter ant and L. gongylophorus relationship. Cellulase is poorly produced by L. gongylophorus (Silvia et al. 2006), however the gongylidia hyphae are full of photolytic enzymes (Boyd & Martin, 1975). When the leaf-cutter ants consume the gongylidia and defecate into the L. gongylophorus growth substrate, they are recycling the enzymes (Stevens 1983). The specialized digestive track of leaf-cutter ants allows the enzymes to pass through without being broken down, maintaining their function (Stevens 1983).

Reproduction by L. gongylophorus is generally thought to be asexual. A queen leaf-cutter ant will store a small inoculum of L. gongylophorus in her buccal pouch (Stevens 1983). After establishing her new colony, the queen will bury the L. gongylophorus inoculum and tend to it with her feces and eggs until it is well established. Once the garden is established, the queen will produce worker ants to tend the garden with leaf material, excrement and saliva (Stevens 1983). While most studies indicate that L. gongylophorus is not capable of producing spores for reproduction, multiple studies have found evidence of the capacity to produce sexual structures (Fisher et al. 1994, Pagnocca et al 2001, Mueller et al 2001), making recombination a possibility (Doherty et al. 2003).

Due to the obligate mutualism between L. gongylophorus and Atta spp., the range of L. gongylophorus is restricted to the southern United States to Northern Argentina (Hölldobler & Wilson 1990). Current studies are further examining the mechanisms behind plant material degradation by L. gongylophorus and the extent of the relationship between L. gongylophorus and leaf-cutter ants.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Monstera is a liana of the monocotyledonous family Araceae, commonly referred to by its genus name (Ray 1983). Monstera is restricted to the Neotropics, particularly moist and wet forests from sea level to 1800m. Found mainly in the geographical range of Southeast Nicaragua to Western Panama (Gargiullo et al. 2008) with a high abundance specifically in La Selva, Costa Rica. According to Ray (1983), the seedlings of Monstera are dropped a few inches from a tree and upon germination exhibit strong, skototropic (tendency to grow towards the shade or darkness) growth towards the base of the closest tree. Until, the seedling reaches the trunk of a tree, it doesn’t produce leaves. The first leaves Monstera produces, when it does reach a tree, are very small, circular leaves with entire margins pressed flat against the trunk. As Monstera ascends into the canopy its leaves get bigger and bigger until when the successive leaves attain a diameter of about 25-30 cm, a dramatic change in leaf occurs. The leaves develop deep clefts and become pinnatifid, having the appearance of fern fronds. Mature leaves can get up to 125 cm long. These mature leaves are capable of returning to the ground, however, when they descend they do not return to their juvenile leaf morphology, but instead retain their mature form (Ray 1983). This unique developmental morphology has attracted much interest in the scientific community and has sparked a debate on possible causes for this leaf modification (Ray 1983, Zuchowski 2005). Some studies suggest that there is a threshold of available light necessary to induce morphological change. A study that tested this hypothesis found that the change in morphology occurred at a lower height in habitats with more available light and that the size of the last juvenile leaf increased with light availability (Pfitsch 1999). Meanwhile some people (Ray 1983) are skeptical of these results. Ray (1983) writes that a tree standing in an open field receives rather uniformly high isolation on the lower portion of the trunk. Yet, when M. tenuis grows on such a trunk, it does not switch to the mature leaf form at the base of the tree. Light may affect the rate at which the changes occur but it does not affect their nature (Ray 1983). Additional characteristics of Monstera include alternate leaves, aerial roots and numerous, small, white flowers on a terminal inflorescence (Gargiullo et al. 2008). These perfect flowers are on a uniform spadix with an erect, concave spathe that falls off when the flower has been successfully pollinated by bees (Zuchowski 2005). These flowers then turn into large infructescences about 30 cm long, containing about a 1,000 fruits each (Ray 1983). The fleshy, yellow fruits provide a reward for birds, which aid in dispersion of seeds. Monstera blooms and fruits most of the year (Zuchowski 2005).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
This nocturnal dung-feeding scarab beetle is found from the southeastern United States to Central America (Howden 1983). The preferred habitat for Dichotomius carolinus appears to be primary forest (Estrada and Coates-Estrada 2002). They will, however, come into nearby openings to feed on dung of horses and cattle (Howden, 1983).

The body length of individuals in this species ranges from 22 to 30 mm (Hogue 1993). This is considered a large dung beetle, and the largest species of dung beetle in Costa Rica (Howden 1983). They are completely black and have a convex body shape. The species lacks teeth and the anterior margin of the head is abruptly rounded (Howden 1983). The elytra have prominent striations that are typically filled with dry soil from digging (Hogue 1993).

They feed almost exclusively on dung of all kinds (Howden 1983) D. carolinus does not roll balls of dung as do some other dung beetles (Scholtz et al. 2009). Upon finding dung they divide it up into irregular fragments and push these fragments directly into a burrow (Hogue 1993). Depending on the soil type and moisture, the burrow the beetle digs is from 15-40 cm in depth. The dung is then consumed by adults or used as a brood mass (Howden 1983). The brood mass formed from the dung fragment only contains one large, whitish egg (Howden 1983). According to Howden, development from egg to pupa takes approximately two months and new adults emerge during moist periods (1983).

D. carolinus are largely nocturnal, with adults beginning activity at dusk. According to White (1998), this species is so powerful that it is difficult to hold it in a clenched fist. The best way to catch these beetles is by using pit fall traps containing feces (Howden 1983).
Dichotomius carolinus colonicus, a nocturnal dung-feeding scarab beetle found from the Southeastern United States to Central America.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Cochlearius cochlearius (Boat-billed Heron) can be about 51 centimeters (20 inches) tall and can weigh up to 600g. A long bushy crest, a black patch at the base of the hind neck, and a white throat and forehead, characterizes the adults. They have pale wings and tails, black wing lining and flank, a dull rusty belly, and yellow-green gular pouch and legs. The gular pouch turns black during the breeding season. Juveniles are mostly brown with buff on the chest and belly (Stiles and Skutch 1989).

These herons can be found in lowlands from Northern Mexico to Western Ecuador, Bolivia, and Northern Argentina. They roost in large groups on vegetation by wooded riverbanks, swamps, ponds and streams. During the breeding season, which goes from June through October (Costa Rica), they are found nesting in smaller colonies in similar places (Stiles and Skutch 1989; Garrigues and Dean 2007). Females lay two, sometimes three, pale blue eggs (Stiles and Skutch 1989).

The Boat-billed Heron belongs to the family Ardeidae which contains other species of herons, night herons, and egrets. All Ardeidae species, apart from the Boat-billed Heron, have long pointed bills used for spearing and snatching prey (Garrigues and Dean 2007). Boat-billed Herons were originally placed in the family Cochleariidae, which was a monotypic family containing only Boat-billed Herons, due to their unique broad bill and its’ different supporting structures. The skull of the Boat-bill Heron was later found to closely resemble that of Nycticorax nycticorax (Black-crowned Night Heron). Because of this close resemblance Boat-billed Herons were moved to the family Ardeidae (Mock 1983).

Several hypotheses have been suggested to explain why the bill is so unique in Boat-billed Herons. One hypothesis proposes that the bill can be touch-sensitive, which would allow the birds to catch fish and shrimp in the water during very dark nights. Unfortunately, anatomical analysis of the bill did not find any specialized tactile receptors. Another hypothesis speculates that opening the bill rapidly would create partial vacuum forcing water and prey into the mouth. This hypothesis also lacks empirical support. It is currently believed that this unusually broad bill probably compensates for the inaccuracy incurred during nocturnal foraging, but it might also have a sound-producing function during courtship (Mock 1983; Kushlan 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Ophiocordyceps unilateralis (order Hypocreales) is a specialized pantropical parasitoidal fungus that infects Camponotus leonardi ants (Pontoppidan et al. 2009, Evans et al. 2011), known as “zombie ants”. Though it may also be found in warm temperate forests, it is much more common in tropical forests of Central America, Africa, Brazil and Thailand (Harmon 2009). The species is identified by its reproductive structure. The stalk is wiry yet flexible, darkly pigmented and extends from the infected ant’s head. Close to its tip is the ascocarp, a small flask-shaped fruiting body (Sung et al. 2007) which releases the spores. Evans et al. (2011) found diversity within the complex, which suggests that there are multiple species within Ophiocordyceps unilateralis which have yet to be defined. Aditionally, each species of the fungus infects a different species of Camponotini ant, demonstrating the specificity of the fungus on its prey.

Once Ophiocordyceps unilateralis spores reach and infect a Camponotus leonardi ant, it effectively modifies its behavior. The fungus manipulates the ant to bite into the underside of a leaf before killing it. This ensures prime location for fungi development (Andersen et al. 2009). By biting the major vein of the leaf, the host secures itself to the substrate and the fungus can then use the host’s decaying body as a resource, a competitive advantage against the many other decomposers in tropical forests (Andersen et al. 2009). As the fungus consumes the deceased host, it grows out of the head so that it can release its spores. The fungal spores reach the ground, infects other C. leonardi ants, and the cycle repeats. The fungi life cycle is so effective that it can wipe out entire colonies (Pontoppidan et al. 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObject.dc:description: It was recently found that there is a hyperparasitic fungus attacking O. unilateralis. David Hughes and his team (2012) argue that only 6.5% of the fungi’s aerial structures successfully produce spores due to another unclassified hyperparastic fungus castrating O. unilateralis. This helps the Camponotus leonardi ant population to increase due to relieved parasitic pressure. These results are important in that they provide new insight within the parasitic relationship between these organisms.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Though many types of fungi are believed to hold pharmaceutical benefits, it is unknown whether O. unilateralis does. However, due to its ability to break through the complex exoskeleton of the ant and control its behavior, Evans et al. (2011) infer that O. unilateralis likely has enzymes that may be of medicinal use. The fungi contains various known and untapped bioactive metabolites that could be a new source of natural drugs for immunomodulatory, antitumor, hypoglycemic and hypocholesterolemic treatments (Xiao & Zhong 2007). The fungus produces red naphthoquinone pigments, which are studied to be used as a dye for food, pharmaceutical manufacturing, and cosmetic products (Unagul et al. 2005).

taxon.reference: Berry, F., & Kress, J. (1991). Heliconia: An Identification Guide. Smithsonian Institution Press.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Heliconia latispatha and other species in the genus Heliconia are herbs characterized by large leaves and showy bracts that contain inverted, single staminode flowers and drupaceous fruits (Berry and Kress 1991). The genus Heliconia was associated with the banana family (Musaceae) and bird-of-paradise family (Strelitziaceae), but is now in Heliconiaceae (Berry and Kress 1991). H. latispatha is characterized by having erect inflorescences with red, yellow, or orange bracts and a yellowish/greenish rachis (Stiles 1983). An additional identifying characteristic of H. latispatha is the large vertically oriented banana like leaves from a short central stem, also referred to as a musoid growth form (Berry and Kress 1991.) All Costa Rican Heliconia are pollinated by hummingbirds and H. latispatha drupaceous fruits are dispersed by birds and mammals (Stiles 1983). H. latispatha is native to tropical America from Mexico to northern South America (Whistler 2000). H. latispatha is the most sun loving member of the Heliconia and is found in exposed areas, like forested stream edge, tree fall gaps, shady second growth and along road/trail sides (Stiles 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description:
Herbivores: Hispine (Chrysomelidae) beetles mate and reproduce in rolled up leaves. Larvae eat rolled leaves (see Strong 1983).

Pollinators: Hummingbirds, occasionally by hermit hummingbirds whose beaks are sickle-shaped, like the flowers, but H. latispatha are primarily pollinated by non-hermit territorial species (see Stiles 1983).

Dispersers: Frugivorous understory birds.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Conservation
dataObject.dc:description: H. latispatha does well in disturbed habitats, including roadsides and gardens.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObject.dc:description: H. latispatha benefits from moderate land transformation and is common.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Cyclicity
dataObject.dc:description: In aseasonal tropical areas, H. latispatha may flower and fruit all year. In more seasonal forest, bracts and flowers will only be seen during the wetter months.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Erect inflorescences with up to 12 spirally arranged canoe-shaped orange-red bracts bearing single or pairs of flowers that are light green to yellow. Bracts contain water if not in very dry conditions. The inflorescence can last for several months. The inflorescences stick up above the foliage, which is musoid - growing from a short above ground stem, with long spirally arranged petioles and large leaf blades. Leaf bases are asymmetric. Fruits are pea-sized drupes that are initially green but ripen to purple-black.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Dispersal
dataObject.dc:description: When the fruit is ripe it turns from green to blue black and the protective floral bract has either rotted or been pushed away and the fruit is exposed to dispersers (Stiles 1983). The mature fruit is a drupe containing one to three seeds and has a hard inner seed protecting layer (Berry and Kress 1991). The fruit’s outer layer is fleshy and attractive to bird and mammal dispersers (Berry and Kress 1991). Fruiting occurs in wet season or year round in aseasonal areas.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Tropical America from Mexio to Northern South America and widely cultivated in gardens.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology
dataObject.dc:description: Prefer open areas in forest, like large treefall gaps, river edges and landslides. Do well on forest edge, roadsides and gardens. Also occur in secondary forest if canopy is somewhat open.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Heliconia latispatha is native to tropical America from Mexico to northern South America (Whistler 2000). In general, Heliconia can be found by forest streams, light gaps, and shady second growth areas (Stiles 1983). H. latispatha is the most heliophilous member of Heliconia found in Costa Rica and is commonly found in full sun areas, like along roadsides, with exposure to high temperatures and desiccation (Stiles 1983). In addition, H. latispatha is common along rivers where periodic flooding prevents large trees from establishing (Stiles 1983). In Costa Rica, H. latispatha can be found up to 1,110 m on the Pacific slope and up to 1,300 m on the Caribbean slope (Stiles 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: H. latispatha is a medium-sized Heliconia with shoots averaging 3-4m in height (Stiles 1983). The actual plant has an underground rhizome which connects multiple shoots and will spread 10-30cm before putting up a new shoot (Stiles 1983). Each shoot is composed of a pseudotrunk 0.5-1.5m in length and 20-35cm in width and is formed by imbricated petiol bases and leaves (Stiles 1983). When each shoot is about one year old it will produce its own erect inflorescence consisting of twelve to seventeen showy bracts (Stiles 1983). The bracts are very noticeable and are orange, red, and/or yellow with yellowish/greenish rachis and are the main visual signal to pollinators (Stiles 1983). H. latispatha exhibits musoid vegetative growth and is characterized by having large banana like leaves orientated vertically with long petioles coming from a short stem that is close to the ground (Berry and Kress 1991).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description:
H. latispatha blooms mainly in June to August during the beginning of the rainy season (in Central America) but inflorescences have been known to occur in any month on the Pacific slope of Costa Rica (Stiles 1983). H. latispatha produces yellow tubular flowers with the perianth averaging 40-45mm in length (Stiles 1983). Each flower secretes sucrose rich nectar that attracts hummingbirds which is the species pollinator (Stiles 1983). After pollination, each flower is protected by a membranaceous bract that covers the ripening fruit for 2-3 months while the fruit ripens (Stiles 1983). When the fruit is ripe it turns from green to blue black and the protective floral bract has either rotted or been pushed away and the fruit is exposed to dispersers (Stiles 1983). The mature fruit is a drupe containing one to three seeds and has a hard inner seed protecting layer (Berry and Kress 1991). The fruit’s outer layer is fleshy and attractive to bird and mammal dispersers (Berry and Kress 1991).

Asexual reproduction also occurs, forming clumps or small groves of plants via underground stems or stems just at the ground.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: H. latispatha is used as an ornamental and for cut flowers.

taxon.reference: DeVries, P. 1987. The butterflies of Costa Rica and their natural history: Vol.1. Chichester: Princeton University Press.
Goode, M. 1999. An introduction to Costa Rican butterflies. San Jose: M.R. Goode.
Young, A. 1971. Mimetic associations in natural populations of tropical Papilionid butterflies. (Lepidoptera: Papilionidae). New York Enomology Society: 79 (4): 210-224.
Young, A. 1973. Notes on the life cycle and natural history of Parides arcas mylotes (Papilionidae) in Costa Rican premontane wet forest. Psyche: 80:1-2.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Parides arcas mylotes, belongs to the “Aristolochia swallowtail” butterfly family (Papilionidae) (Young, 1971). This species ranges from Mexico to Venezuela, in all forest habitats on both slopes up to 1,400 m (DeVries, 1987).Young (1973) reports that Adults of both sexes are commonly encountered along paths, natural clearings, swamp edges, and other exposed areas that either border forest or those which are found in the forest interior (Young, 1973). The same author also reports that caterpillars of this species are usually found on several species of Aristolochia vines for feeding and oviposition. Species of at least two other genera in the Papilionidae family are also known to feed on Aristolochia, due to the high alkaloid content of the leaves of these vines (Young, 1971). Adult P. arcas mylotes can be found on a variety of flowers, usually ranging from red to purple (DeVries, 1987; Young, 1973).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description: Adults of both sexes generally cruise very low over well-lit, second growth vegetation. Although courtship activity is limited to the sunniest hours of the morning, adults of both sexes generally forage throughout the day, and are relatively unaffected by changes in local weather conditions (Young, 1973). Within Costa Rica, an explanation of mimicry, or protective morphological resemblance, may be made upon the premise of a bird such as a jacamar (Galbulidae) attacking a noxious and foul-tasting butterfly, such as an individual P. arcas mylotes, which uses Papilio anchisiades as a model for mimicry (Goode, 1999). The bird captures the butterfly, removes its wings and proceeds to swallow it. Shortly afterwards, it vomits up the toxic and distasteful remains of the insect and wipes the residues upon the branch it was perching on (Goode, 1999). This experience will discourage the bird from attacking any species of butterfly that belongs to the same family as P. arcas mylotes. When the bird observes an example of Papilio anchisiades (Papilionidae), which belongs to the same family and is morphologically similar, it will likely pass it over as prospective meat, even though the mimic may be edible. It is therefore beneficial for the mimic to resemble its model as closely as possible (Goode, 1999).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObject.dc:description:
The egg is a dark rusty-brown and slightly flattened at the base, with a diameter of 1.1 mm (Young, 1973). The egg is covered with a thick layer of an orange-red sticky substance, which attaches it to the leaf surface. This sticky substance forms thin threads, which hang down from the upper half of the egg and assist in attachment (Young, 1973). Eggs are laid on the ventral surface of older, well-shaded leaves, occasionally in the forks of small stems and petioles. Eggs are laid singly, but usually in clusters of two to five on a single leaf (Young, 1973).

The first instar is about 3.2 mm long when it hatches, with a dark orange-brown body. After the young larva begins to feed on leaf tissue, the body color becomes a deep red. All segments bear long tubercles of the same color as the body. By the tie of the first molt, the larva is about 9 mm (Young, 1973). Young (1973) also reports that the second instar is remarkably similar to the first, the only difference being a loss of the spines seen on tubercles in the previous instar. By the second molt the larva is 14 mm long. The third instar is an exact replica of the second instar except that the color of the body is a deep purplish black, with larva at a length of 23 mm (Young, 1973). Young 91973) also describes that the fourth instar is identical to the last, except that the skin is particularly shiny and reflective, with a length of 35 mm by the fourth molt. A dramatic change occurs with the molt to the fifth instar. The dark body color gradually lightens as extensively grayish-tan areas replace the formerly purplish-brown areas of the body, with each tubercle bearing lines of white in addition to the mottled coloration of the body color. By the time of pupation, the larva is about 45 mm long (Young, 1973).

The larva is most likely warning-colored, due to their unpalatable taste and toxicity, with great contrast against the light green leaves of the food plant (Goode, 1999;Young, 1973). The pupa is approximately 25 mm long, with a color pattern consisting of various light shades of green and yellow. The frontal portions of the thorax and abdomen in the pupa are yellow, while the rest of the body is light green (Young, 1973). Adults are noticeably sexually dimorphic; the mean length of the forewing in females is about 40 mm, while that of the male’s is about 38 mm (DeVries, 1987; Young 1973). The single light area of the dorsal surface of the forewing in the female is cream-colored while the dorsal bands on the hindwings are orange-red (Young, 1973). The large spot on each forewing of males is light green, with a cream-colored apical portion (Young, 1973). In bright sunlight, the red patches of the male’s hindwing are iridescent, giving off a purple luster; this morphological property is not seen in females (Young 1973).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy
http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: Habitat selection for courtship is determined by two factors: establishment of ideal sites by males in sunlight second-growth bordering forest clearings, and the response by mated females to become more prone to disperse in search for oviposition sites (Young, 1973). Courtship is limited to the sunniest part of the mornings. A courtship strategy of males in which they constantly patrol an area of the habitat day after day and mate with females as the latter emerge from their pupae, is common for butterflies in which males are shorter-lived than females, as is the case with Parides (Young, 1973). Mating females in search of oviposition, or egg depositing, sites perform sudden, nearly vertical darts into the canopy where Aristolochia lianas are found. Such cruising patterns by egg-laying females indicate well-developed food plant specialization in P. arcas mylotes (Young, 1973). Upon landing on a leaf for oviposition, females exhibit considerable wing fluttering and drumming behavior with the antennae; an egg is then laid within 12 seconds (Young, 1973). While males cruise in the general vicinity of egg-laying females, there are virtually no observable interactions between sexes (Young, 1973). Males constantly patrol an area of habitat day after day and mate with females as soon as they emerge from their pupae. The latter is a common strategy for butterflies in which are shorter-lived than females, as is the case with Parides (Young, 1973).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
The Ox Eye liana (Family Fabaceae: Papilionoideae) is found from Nicaragua to South America, and is widespread in Costa Rica from 500-2,000 m elevation (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2005). This is one of seven Mucuna species in Costa Rica and is most common at high elevations and forest edges (Gargiullo et al. 2008). Its common name in Spanish, picapica, roughly translates to “itchitch” and refers to the urticating, itchy hairs that cover the flowers and fruit pods (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2005). This woody liana has large trifoliate leaves with entire margins and spaced secondary veins, and a swollen pulvinus (Gentry & Vasquez 1996). It also has asymmetrical veins and leaflets. Because it is a liana, it grows spiraled around other plants in the area. The Ox Eye inflorescence contains zygomorphic, pealike flowers with 10 stamens, and the greenish, cream-colored flowers are arranged in a spiral in groups of three on the stem (Smith et al. 2004, Zuchowski & Forsyth 2005). This hanging chandelier-like cluster on the liana is found on the end of the peduncles, which can be of varying lengths up to 10m (Agostini et al. 2006).

Although most members of the Papilionoideae subfamily are pollinated by bees, this genus is pollinated by bats; specifically, the Ox Eye is pollinated by the nectivorous small bat Glossophaga soricina (Agostini et al. 2011). Glossophaga finds the flowers using an acoustic nectar guide that reflect echolocation signals back to the bat so it can more easily find the flower, a technique seen in several Mucuna species (von Helversen & von Helversen 1999). The Ox Eye has also been recorded as being pollinated by the omnivorous bat Anoura caudifer and Hylonycteris species, though not as often as G. soricina (Sazima et al. 1999, Zuchowski & Forsyth 2005). Agostini et al. (2006) found that as the bats probe for nectar, the flowers project pollen onto the pollinators in an explosive fashion after pressure has been applied to the flower. When this flower opening mechanism is activated, the flower immediately ceases nectar production to begin fruit development (Agostini et al. 2011). Some bees and hummingbirds have been observed as “nectar robbers” that drill holes and steal nectar from the flower during the day without pollinated the flower.

Fruits of the Ox Eye are large, dehiscent brown pods (about 15cm long) with a wrinkled appearance, covered in irritating golden hairs (Zuchowski & Forsyth 2005). Each pod contains around three large black seeds. Cental American agoutis (Dasyprocta punctata) act as both seed predators and seed dispersers for the Ox Eye by either immediately eating the seed or cache the seeds to eat later and forget after burying them (O’Dell 2000). The seeds also contain toxic compounds to deter parasitism by bruchid beetles (O’Dell 2000, Smith et al. 2004).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Ant lions are found worldwide, in tropical and subtropical regions in Africa, Asia, Australia, and the Americas (Resh and Cardé 2003). They live in arid and semiarid areas of open woodlands, scrub grasses, and dry sandy areas (Resh and Cardé 2003). They are more abundant in lower rainfall areas since the larvae require dry and loose soil (McClure 1983). However, the larvae can also be found in areas protected from rain in regions with higher rainfall (McClure 1983).

Ant lions are holometabolus, which means that they undergo complete metamorphosis, and larvae are morphologically very different from adults. Morphologically, adults are similar to damselflies, but they have a few differences. Adult ant lions have softer bodies, pointed wing tips, different wing venation, and long, clubbed antennae (Borror and White 1970, McClure 1983). Adults are 5-6 cm in length and thin-bodied, and they have broad pronotums and prominent compound eyes (McClure 1983). Eggs are unstalked, relatively large, and covered with an adhesive glandular secretion (Resh and Cardé 2003). They are laid singly in dry, loose soil in open areas or under shelter (McClure 1983, Resh and Cardé 2003).

Larvae are rough, squat, and wedge-shaped (McClure 1983). They have long, sickle-like jaws, posteriorly tapered abdomens, flat heads, metathoracic legs (with fused tibia and tarsus), enlarged, forward-directed claws, and forward-directed bristles on their bodies (Borror and White 1970, McClure 1983). Larval development can occur over several years depending on prey availability, and while the average time spent as a larva is two years, it can last longer than three years (McClure 1983). This variability results in large ranges of sizes of larvae that hatched around the same size in a given location (Resh and Cardé 2003, McClure 1983). Larvae have three instars, and fully-grown larvae are 10-12 mm in length (McClure 1983, Resh and Cardé 2003). Cocoons are spherical, single-walled, 10-15 mm in diameter, and are made of sand and silk (McClure 1983, Resh and Cardé 2003).

When a larva hatches, it moves backwards in an irregular pattern to find a suitable location for a pit (McClure 1983). The larva then digs a conical pit by plowing backwards in a circle and flicking sand upwards with its head (McClure 1983). Pits are 1-4 cm in diameter (McClure 1983). The larva remains concealed at the bottom of its pit and waits for prey (McClure 1983). Many studies have been conducted on ant lion larvae, especially on pits and competition (Burgess 2009, Scharf et al. 2008, Swenson et al. 2007).

Both larvae and adult ant lions are predaceous (McClure 1983). Larvae eat ants and other small arthropods that fall into their pits (Resh and Cardé 2003). A larva feeds by using its piercing mandibles to grab the fallen prey, and it injects digestive enzymes into the prey (McClure 1983, Resh and Cardé 2003). After a few minutes, the larva sucks the liquids out, and finally, it flicks the remains out of the pit with its head (Resh and Cardé 2003, McClure 1983). Adults are also predaceous on small arthropods, and they are crepuscular or nocturnal (McClure 1983).

Lastly, adult males use extrusions of hair pencils and abdominal glands/sacs for sexual communication (Resh and Cardé 2003). Male and female adults can also release volatile substances from thoracic glands (Resh and Cardé 2003).
