dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Avicennia germinans, commonly known as the black mangrove, is found in tropical and subtropical mangrove forests ranging from the southeastern United States in North America to Brazil in South America. It is found along both coasts of Central America, as well as West Africa and Australia (Kathiresan and Bingham 2001). They flourish in brackish waters, where tidal ocean saltwater mixes with freshwater from streams, and thus must be able to withstand a wide range of salinities (Suarez et al. 1998). A. germinans is a shrub or tree that can reach up to 20 m tall and is characterized by distinct root structures known as pneumatophores (Zuchowski 2007). The trunk is straight and the grey bark is generally fissured. The simple opposite leaves are long and narrow, often shiny green and leathery, and have short petioles (Condit et al. 2011).

Like all mangroves, A. germinans is adapted to deal with high salt environments in muddy, anaerobic soils. A. germinans has a very large salt tolerance, ranging from freshwater to water with three times the salinity of seawater (Sobrado 1999). This reflects the ability of this tree to grow in saltwater basins that frequently exhibit salinity higher than that of seawater (Saenger 2002). A. germinans is able to withstand these intense salinity levels through the ability to excrete salt through glands on the surface of the leaves, increasing the salt tolerance of the plant (Griffiths 2008).

Thin, pencil-like pneumatophores emerge from the thick mud substrate in which the tree is found, an adaption that allows A. germinans to colonize anaerobic substrates (Thibodeau and Nickerson 1986). These root structures aid in gas exchange when they are exposed to the air, a mechanism that allows this tree to flourish even though the substrate conditions fail to provide the tree with necessary oxygen (Tomlinson 1994). The pneumatophores are connected to a horizontal root system that allows the tree to send roots wide in search of nutrients and oxygen, but not deep into the anaerobic soil (Zuchowski 2007).

Small insects and bees are thought to pollinate A. germinans (Landry 2013). Water remains the key dispersal mechanism. A. germinans seedlings are equipped for this dispersal method due to their buoyancy, high salinity tolerance, and cryptoviviparous nature (Alleman and Hester 2011). Propagules germinate on the mother tree and the seedling pierces the seed coat but not the pericarp, allowing the germinated seedling to experience maximum nutrient acquisition while still maintaining the ability to withstand long dispersal times in saltwater (Das and Ghose 2003).

Conservation of A. germinans remains an important and contested issue in many areas. As shorelines are being developed more and more mangrove forests are being cut down (Valiela et al 2001). These mangrove forests are not only important homes for wildlife, but also help to reduce erosion of shoreline in tidal salt marshes and maintain barrier islands, which are an important natural protection from tropical storms. The pneumatophores help to trap organic matter and sediment, and can actually be used to rebuild shorelines and restore wetland habitats (United States Department of Agriculture 2005).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Species of the genus Pterois (more commonly known as lionfish, turkeyfish, dragonfish) belong to the family Scorpaenidae which includes many known species of venomous marine fish that can live up to 15 years and be up to 40cm standard length. Lionfish are native to the Indo-Pacific however, in 1992 an invasion of P. volitans and P. miles broke out in Key Biscayne, Florida. Today, lionfish have spread all around the Caribbean with several sightings as far north on the Gulf Stream as Rhode Island and Bermuda (Schofield 2009). Efforts to control the populations of P. volitans and P. miles include exemption of fishing permits and limits in the state of Florida as well as community-run derbies. Lionfish are also being served as a delicacy in restaurants.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology
dataObject.dc:description: Sharks and the cornetfish, Fistularia commersonii, are suggested as natural predators (Steinitz 1959) whereas green moray, Gymnothorax funebris, and native groupers have been known to ingest injured lionfish in the Bahamas (Maljkovic et al. 2008).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Most species of Pterois are reef associated, hiding under rocky outcroppings during the day and moving to deeper water to hunt at night. Pterois volitans and Pterois miles are also mangrove associated, sometimes migrating up estuarine systems into low salinity environments. Usually distributed between 1m and 60m deep, however, some species have been recorded as deep as 300m (REEF 2012) indicating great capability to adapt to numerous conditions. Over the course of ten months, individuals have been recorded to move only an average of 28m, exhibiting high site fidelity (Jud and Layman 2012) and contributing heavily to shaping the community structure along coastline habitats.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: Characterized by conspicuous red, white, and black aposematism, or warning colorations, Pterois have numerous (12-13) dorsal spines, 3 anal spines, and 9-11 frilly fin rays (Eschmeyer 1986) that differentiate them from other Scorpaeniformes. The most notable feature of the genus Pterois are the venomous spines located dorsally and anally on the body of the fish. The colorful spines contain toxins and fin rays are used to attract prey and mates. Lionfish pectoral and pelvic fins are spread latero-ventrally while keeping the dorsal fin erect which deters frontal assaults by predators. Pteroine toxins significantly prevent predation and in many instances kill test fish within 30 minutes of injection (Bernadsky and Goulet 1991). At the base of each spine is a venom gland that feeds a narrow groove up the length of the spine. When the spine is depressed, an integumentary sheath exposes the neurotoxin into the puncture wound (Attis 2010).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#RiskStatement
dataObject.dc:description: In a meta-analysis conducted by Cote et al. (2013), the effect of invasive lionfish in the Caribbean was found to be compounded by continuous reproduction and high fecundity of individuals, rapid life-history, and intense competition with native species. Adult females produce between 10,000 and 40,000 eggs per spawning event, releasing eggs on a continuous basis when conditions are favorable. Spawning events have been observed to occur appoximately every 4 days in warm summer months, perhaps increasing in frequency in the more southern extensions of its introduced range leading to an average annual fecundity exceeding 2 million eggs per female. Individuals have also been shown to grow more rapidly in their invaded range when compared to growth rates in the native Pacific range, becoming sexually mature within the first year of life. The meta-analysis also point out that the invasive lionfish have superior competitive abilities over native species, achieving faster growth and maturity than natives. The naivete of prey, being unaccustomed to lionfish as a predator, allow lionfish to indirectly outcompete native piscivorous fish species. Being generalist feeders, lionfish prey on a wide range of native species which decreases the abundance of reef fishes and recruits of larger species that would otherwise outgrow lionfish (Cote et al.2013). Lionfish feed almost continuously, sometimes consuming fish up to almost half their size, effectively slowing stock regeneration of native fish species (Morris and Akins 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TrophicStrategy
dataObject.dc:description: Individuals of the genus Pterois primarily eat smaller reef fishes as well as crustaceans actively and almost continuously throughout the course of a day with decreased feeding activity during the afternoon. The presence of a bilateral swim bladder aids in highly skilled maneuvering and ambush of prey (Morris and Akins 2009). Often a jet of water is used to disorient and distract prey before they are ingested in one swift motion, usually head first (Albins and Lyons 2012).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Morpho peleides, or the Blue Morpho, is one of the most well-known Neotropical butterflies due to its striking iridescent blue wings. M. peleides is sometimes considered a subspecies of M. helenor (Gerardo Lamas, (2004) Atlas of Neotropical Lepidoptera; Checklist: Part 4A; Hesperioidea – Papilionoidea). It is commonly found along forest trails, banana and coffee plantations, and woodland streams up an elevation of 1600 meters (DeVries 1987). It has a natural distribution from Mexico down to Northern South America (Janzen 2010). More specifically, Costa Rican habitats that harbor M. peleides include Pacific lowland evergreens (0-800m), Pacific mid-elevation (700-1600m), and Atlantic lowlands (0-500m) (DeVries 1987).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObject.dc:description: The egg of the Morpho is hemispherical and green in coloration, which helps it blend in with the upper leaves where it is laid. Eggs are laid singly, usually only one egg is affixed to a leaf, although anywhere from 1-8 eggs may be laid on a single plant (Young & Muyshondt 1973). It takes up to 12 days for the egg to hatch (Goode 1999). During this time, the egg may change color many times to help camouflage them from predators. When first laid they are white or yellowish-green and will change to a richer green or brown depending on the substrate where they are laid (Goode 1999). Twenty-four hours prior to hatching, the egg takes on a shining dark brown-to-black color (Young & Muyshondt 1973). Once hatched, the larva, or caterpillar, eats its nutrient-rich eggshell. The caterpillars are colored brown, red and yellow, and ornamented with colorful tufts of hair (Goode 1999). The larva consists of a sclerotized head and 13 segments. The head bears simple eyes and hard mandibles. It also has 3 pairs of “true legs”, one on each thoracic segment. Finally, near the base of the mandibles are two small antennae important for distinguishing food (DeVries 1987). When Morpho caterpillars are mature they lose their bright colorations and develop excellent cryptic patternings (Goode 1999). The larva will feed on about 23 different species of plants, including Mimosoid and Papilionoid legumes (Fabaceae), including Macharium, Pterocarpus, Swartzia, Dalbergia, Mucuna, Lonchocarpus, Platymyscium and Paragonia (Bignoniaceae; DeVries 1987. There are five larval instars (Goode 1999). The entire caterpillar stage in M. peleides lasts roughly eight weeks before forming the chrysalis. The larva will anchor itself to the substrate, generally a twig or large leaf, and will rest between 36-48 hours while the chrysalis develops beneath the larval skin. The larval skin splits along sutures on its back to reveal the chrysalis. The chrysalis stage will last from a week to a few months. Weather plays a large factor in the duration, as they like to synchronize their emergence with the arrival of seasonal rains. In places where rain is extremely common, the Blue Morpho can mate year round and the chrysalis stage is short (Goode 1999). When the butterfly is ready to emerge, the skin fractures where the head and legs are positioned so that it may squeeze itself out of its shell. At first the butterfly’s wings are very small, but over the course of the next few minutes it will pump blood into its wings, drastically increasing their size until they are fully expanded. After this the upper and lower membranes fuse together and harden. This process can take several hours, leaving it vulnerable to attack. Once the wings are dried, the butterfly flies off (Goode 1999).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: The Blue Morpho is easily recognized by its iridescent blue wings, whose color is a combination of a dark pigmented undercoat and a layer of refractory scales above. Iridescence is from diffraction of light off these upper wing scales. The ventral side of the wings is brown and black with 4 yellow “eyespots” that act as targets for predators to avoid aiming for the head or body (Goode 1999). They have a wingspan of 12.7-15.5 centimeters and a very irregular flight pattern, which can be partially attributed to its fermented diet (Henderson et al. 2010).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description:
Courtship rituals consist of various flying patterns such as zig-zag patterns or hovering beside each other. Males often follow females, transferring pheromones as they do so. If a male nears a female who is ready to mate, he lands and then they quickly mate, sometimes without any courtship ritual (Henderson et al. 2010). Mating can last from 15 minutes to 3 hours, but most rituals last about 30-40 minutes (Scott 1986). The main purpose of courtship is to make certain that the other butterfly is a healthy member of the right species.

In some cases, females display rejection behaviors. One such “rejection dance” involves the female to fly vertically in the air and then quickly dives downward to keep the male from following her (Scott 1986). In another rejection behavior the female attempts to mimic a male by flapping her wings vigorously.

Males often need about one day to finish maturing before they can mate. However females usually mate immediately and sometimes males even wait by the chrysalis before she emerges (Scott 1986).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TrophicStrategy
dataObject.dc:description: The Morpho peleides feeds solely on leaves as a larva and then once transformed into a butterfly becomes nearly a complete frugivore. Once fully transformed, the butterfly feeds on fermented fruit and the occasional sap flow (Miller 2006). As stated above, this is the reason for its sporadic flight pattern. One interesting characteristic of M. peleides is that it exhibits territoriality, which is rare or absent in most butterfly species. Once a territory has been established, males will actively defend it by chasing rivals away (Scott 1986).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Brassavola nodosa

Also known as: Brassavola venosa, Epidendrum nodosum (Fanfani & Rossi, 1988)

Brassavola nodosa or the Lady of the Night orchid is a clump forming, epiphytic or lithophytic member of the Orchidaceae family (Fanfani & Rossi, 1988).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description: Hawk moths (Lepidoptera: Sphingidae) are the primary pollinators of B. nodosa flowers. A single pollinator will visit the flower to remove the entire pollinarium, or male unit, which contains eight pollinia (Schemske, 1980). It is easy to tell if a B. nodosa has been visited by the absence of this pollinarium. The removal of the pollinarium does not indicate if the flower was pollinated, however, as this requires the pollinium be delivered to the stigma. Once the flower has been pollinated and fertilization occurs, the fruit immediately begins to develop. B. nodosa is self-compatible but not autogamous (Schemske, 1980). The fruit becomes a dehiscent dry capsule with thousands of tiny, wind-dispersed seeds (Winkler et al., 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description: B. nodosa is a perennial (United States Department of Agriculture) that flowers primarily in the late rainy season, which is from August to November. The flowers have a long lifespan of about 14 to 21 days if they are not pollinated (Schemske, 1980).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: B. nodosa is native to the lowland coastal regions of Central and South America and can be found growing on trees trunks and branches (as epiphytes) in lowland tropical forests, mangrove swamps or on bare rocks and cliffs by the seashore (as lithophytes; Schemske, 1980). It is widespread from Mexico to Colombia, with populations stretching into Venezuela, Brazil, Bolivia, Peru, and the Caribbean islands (Mahr, 2004).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description:
List of species and varieties within genus Brassavola family Orchidaceae (Mexico and Central America) and how to differentiate Brassavola nodosa (Jones, 1973):

1. B. digbyana

Range: Mexico, British Honduras, Guatemala, Honduras. Has characteristic deeply fringed margin of labellum, widely cultivated and used in the creation of hundreds of horticultural hybrids.

2. B. glauca

Range: Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, Panama. Closely related to B. digbyana, but is smaller and does not have the deeply fringed margin of the labellum characteristic of that species.

3. B. digbyana var. fimbripetala

Range: endemic to Honduras. This variety has fringed margins of the petals and labellum.

4. B. cucullata, B. cuspidate, B. odoraitissima, B. elongata

Range: Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, West Indies, northern South America. Common and widely distributed throughout the New World tropics.

5. B. cucullata var. elegans, B. appendiculata

Range: Mexico, Guatemala. This variety is distinguished from the type by smaller flowers and shorter pedicellate ovaries.

6. B. rhopalorrhachis, B. nodosa var. rhopalorrhachis

Range: Guatemala, Panama. Related to B. nodosa and B. gillettei (a West Indian species). Has a flowerscape with a branched summit that distinguishes it from all other species of the genus.

7. B. nodosa (Epidendrum nodosum), B. stricta, B. scaposa

Range: Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, British Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama, West Indies, South America. Most geographically widespread species of the entire genus. Characterized by the narrow, tube-like base of the labellum.

8. B. nodosa var. venosa, B. venosa

Range: Honduras, Guatemala. This variety is distinguished from the type by the broken margins of the labellum.

9. B. nodosa var. grandiflora, B. grandiflora

Range: Nicaragua, West Indies. Size of flowers are twice as large as B. nodosa var. venosa and B. venosa and has differently shaped labellum.

10. B. acaulis, B. mathieuana

Range: Guatemala, Panama, Costa Rica. Floral and vegetative characteristics are very similar to B. nodosa, but the flowers are borne singly on a lateral peduncle.

11. B. lineata

Range: Guatemala, Panama. Closely related to B. acaulis and B. mathieuana, but has longer and narrower leaves, the inflorescence bears 2-3 flowers, the labellum is proportionately narrower and pure white, without any of the purple flecks found in B. acaulis.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: B. nodosa ranges in height from 15 to 18 inches (38-46 cm) with a short, cylindrical swelling called a pseudobulb that is used to store water and nutrients (Heywood et al., 2007). Clumps have several single grey-green leaves that ranges from 10-30 cm long and from 0.3-1.8 cm wide (Baker & Baker, 1997). The leaf is linear and erect with a fleshy interior, stiff exterior, and a channeled upper surface. This results in a subterete or semicylindrical appearance (Mahr, 2004). B. nodosa only hosts one inflorescence per stem and it shoots out from the leaf axil as a new growth matures. This inflorescence is usually 8 inches (20 cm) long (Baker & Baker, 1997) with one to six pale green and white flowers that are 3.5 to 6 inches (9-15 cm) in diameter (Mahr, 2004). All of these flowers open simultaneously when the plant blooms (Schemske, 1980). B. nodosa is a monocot so these flowers are monosymmetric with three sepals, three petals, and a gynoecium with a tricarpellate, inferior ovary (Endress, 1994). All sepals and two of the petals are long and slender and can be pale green, light yellow, or pure white (Baker & Baker, 1997). B. nodosa can also be recognized by its large, third petal that is a tubular lip. This lip petal opens to produce a heart-shaped terminal area that is around 2 inches (5 cm) wide and has characteristic purple or red spots at its base (Baker & Baker, 1997).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Canavalia rosea (Family Fabacaea, Subfamily Papilionoidea) is a pantropical and subtropical plant found along the beach just above high tide in the berm (Gross 1993). This Pantropical and Subtropical plant ranges from sea level to 200 M. and is not very salt tolerant. It is a creeping plant with long stems that may extend anywhere between seven and ten meters (Kitajima et al 2008). Leaf characteristics of this plant include three compound rounded leaflets about 7 cm. in diameter (Kitajima et al 2008). The leaves are thick and shiny, are shaped oval to oblong, and they contain a blunt tip and base. During the most intense heat of the day, these leaves will fold in on themselves. The flowers are inflorescences of sparse clusters that bloom most of the year. The inflorescences are asymmetrical flowers about two inches long of light purple with a white center (Garguillo 2008). These inflorescences are normally pollinated by bees, and in Japan are pollinated by female leaf cutter bees (Matsumara 2004). The fruit of C. rosea is a dry, flat, bean pod about 15 cm long and 2 cm wide. The bean pod will contain 6 dry buoyant seeds that are dispersed by water (VatanParast 2011).

C. rosea roots help to hold sand and keep dunes from eroding too much (Seena et al 2005). This plant is a hardy plant and if a fragment of the plant breaks off and if that fragment contains a node, the fragment has roots and is able to start to grow a new plant (Chen et al 2000). The stems are rather woody and branch out from the base covering large areas of beach.

Each part of the plant is often used by natives for homemade uses. Tough toxic, young seeds can be eaten after soaking, and are often done by fishermen and coastal dwellers. If roots are infused, they can be used to treat aches, pains, and rheumatism. The leaves help to relieve pain and with burns. When seeds are crushed they can be used as a substitute for coffee. Fresh dried flowers of C. rosea can be used in cooking as garnish or as flavoring (Britto et al 2010). Often times this plant is found alongside the Ipomoea pes-caprae (Convululaceae) the beach morning glory (Gargiullo et al 2008).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description: Costus laevis (Costaceae) is an understory shrub that is found in the New World Tropics, from Guatemala to Bolivia at altidudes of 0-900 m (Gargiullo et al. 2008). It is found in lowland wet forests and prefers light gaps along streams, roads, and in forests. They require light gaps for germination and establishment but they can continue to fruit and flower if the forest regenerates and they become shaded (Schemske 1983a). The leaf arrangement of C. laevis is simple, alternate in a spiral growth with the leaves being long, pointed and about 15-60 cm long and 5-15 cm in width (Gargiullo et al. 2008). Petioles are sheathed, giving leaves a sessile appearance. The plant can grow up to 1-6 m tall with the youngest growth being red (Gargiullo et al. 2008). The flowers of C. laevis are asymmetrical and white with yellow center and have a large projecting labellum that is dark red with pale yellow stripes and they tend to be 5-9 cm long (Gargiullo et al. 2008, Schemske 1982). Flowers are formed on a pinecone inflorescence that is composed of broad overlapping green bracts that cover the immature flowers (Schemske 1983b). They flower one or two at a time and open at dawn and fall in the afternoon (Schemske 1983b). C. laevis can flower all year, but peak flowering is from May to August, which is the early to middle of the rainy season (Schemske 1983b). The primary pollinators are female euglossine bees, being responsible for 95% of the pollination (Schemske 1983b). Hummingbirds or self-compatibility do the other 5% but this is extremely rare (Schemske 1983b). The fruits of C. laevis are black seeds covered in a waxy white aril that are 2-3mm long (Schemske 1983b). The plant fruits from September to October when the bract opens to reveal the fruits. The white fruit contrast with the bright red of the inner bract. This display attracts birds that eat the white aril and disperse the seeds (Schemske 1983a). A common predator is the blue-black grosbeak, which is an understory finch that eats mature or immature fruits by opening the bracts and eating the seeds (Schemske 1983b). Another predator is Cholus cinctus (a black and yellow weevil) that drills into the bracts destroying the new flower buds and the inflorescence in general. Mostly the weevils just decrease the amount of flower production by destroying part some of the bracts (Schemske 1983b). To decrease the amount of predators on the plant, C. laevis has extrafloral nectaries that attract as many as 24 species of ants to protect the plant and decrease the amount of predation. Bracts near mature flowers have active nectar sites. The plant may have evolved a specific morphology and chemical characteristics to increase its chances of having an ant species visit it with the best defense mechanisms (Schemske 1982). Monacis bispinosus and Ectatomma tuberculatum ants mostly protect Costus laevis according to a study by Schemske but they do not give protection against weevils. Only when Azteca ants were present on C. laevis is it free from predators (Schemske 1983b).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
A rotund, egg-shaped amphibian, the Northern Sheep Frog (Hypopachus variolosus) inhabits dry and moist forests of lowland and premontane zones from southeastern Texas, USA, to central Costa Rica (Savage 2002), mainly below 1000 m in elevation but up to 2200 m on the Mexican plateau (Nelson 1974). A thick skin fold on the neck and a triangular snout readily identify this species as a member of the Microhylidae family; another distinctive feature includes the pair of metatarsal tubercles, or spades, on each hind leg (Leenders 2001). Typically, a smattering of dark patches and a single yellow streak extend down the gray, olive, and brown dorsum, with a similar light stripe standing out amongst the dark mottling of the white or grey belly (Conant & Collins 1991; Leenders 2001). A white diagonal stripe runs from each golden eye the towards the front limbs, usually with a dark eyemask also present (Leenders 2001). Adults measure roughly 30 to 50 mm in length, with females being the larger sex and lacking the dark throat coloration of males (Savage 2002). Stocky limbs, unwebbed digits, and nostrils near the very tip of the snout also characterize the body of the Sheep Frog (Savage 2002).

The species prefers areas dominated by short grasses, leading it to often be found in disturbed areas, particularly pastures and open woodlands (Nelson 1974). Secretive and strictly nocturnal, H. variolosus lives underneath rocks or logs, or underground (Leenders 2001). Locomotion primarily involves hopping as well as backward 'sliding' to burrow; the frog's sharp heel tubercles aid in the creation of a burrow which may stretch up to 1 m below the surface (but is less deep during the wet season) (Savage 2002).

When threatened, Sheep Frogs tend to freeze and rely on camouflage, though their stubby legs may power surprisingly lengthy jumps to allow escape (Leenders 2001). They also produce heavy mucous secretions which are irritating to the skin and eyes of humans—and can often stimulate sneezing spells in one who handles a Sheep Frog (Savage 2002). The main predators of the species, namely frog-eating snakes of the genera Leptodeira (cat-eyed snakes) and Coniophanes (black-striped snakes), however, do not seem deterred by these mucous secretions; instead, these secretions appear to better serve as a means to discourage stings from insects (Savage 2002). As the diet of these frogs consists primarily of ants and termites, they will actively forage for high concentrations of these prey underground (Leenders 2001).

H. variolosus employs a reproductive strategy known as explosive breeding: Though the frogs spend the majority of the year in a subterranean existence, following the first heavy rains of the rainy season (or flooding by irrigation), they surface (Conant and Collins 1991). Breeding commences in temporary pools, marshy sites, or standing water in pastures and agricultural fields (Savage 2002). While floating, sexually active males produce a nasal advertisement call resembling a sheep's bleat, spanning roughly two seconds, and rarely being repeated at less than fifteen-second intervals (Conant & Collins 1991). They display a shift from stationary to actively swimming behavior with increasing chorus size and density that may be an adaptation for both predator avoidance and competition for mates (Nelson 1973). Females lay 600 to 800 eggs in a loose mass on the water's surface (Savage 2002). Within twelve hours hatching occurs, and, facing transient ponds, tadpoles develop rapidly, metamorphosing into froglets in about thirty days (Leenders 2001; Savage 2002). The tadpoles lack tooth rows and beaks but possess oral flaps that are papillate or scalloped (Lips & Savage 1996). Though their diet has not been studied, their oral anatomy suggests they are generalized feeders, consuming a variety of organic and inorganic material (Judd & Irwin 2005).

The IUCN Red List has categorized the Sheep Frog as a Species of Least Concern, owing to its wide distribution, generalist habitat tolerance, and presumed large population (Santos-Barrera et al. 2013); the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, however, currently lists the frog as Threatened and prohibits its collection (Judd & Irwin 2005).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Luehea candida trees can be up to 20 m tall and occupy a position in the lower canopy of a tropical dry forest. Individual trees often either exhibit multiple trunks or branch relatively low to the ground. Leaves are large; pubescent with short, fine trichomes; and exhibit palmate venation. Flowers are 7-8 cm in diameter and white with 5 petals and several hundred stamens and stamenodes. Fruits are woody, dehiscent, 5 sectioned, 5-8 cm long pods covered in golden brown trichomes (Haber and Frankie 1983).

This plant species is a wind-dispersed pioneer found at elevations up to 1,100 m from Mexico to Colombia. It can be found in tropical dry uplands as well as in evergreen forest communities adjecent to large rivers. It is leafless from January to April and new leaves flush during the first rains of the wet season (Haber and Frankie 1983). This species flowers after the first heavy rains of the wet season, which often fall from late May to early July (Frankie et. al. 1974). Individuals near irrigated areas may also be found flowering in February or March of the dry season. Flowers open an hour or two after dark and release a fragrance to attract pollinators upon opening. The primary pollinators are many species of hawkmoths, which are attracted both by the scent and by the large amounts of nectar produced by the flowers (Haber and Frankie 1982). Nectar secretion ceases after dawn but residual nectar and pollen attract a variety of hummingbirds, bees, and butterflies during the day that have been shown to be poor pollinators for the species (Haber and Frankie 1982).

The fruits develop for the rest of the wet season and into the dry season, finally maturing in February and March (Frankie et al. 1974). When the pods dehisce they release several winged seeds, that are dispersed by the wind. Seeds can be eaten by rodents and monkeys after they fall or by moth caterpillars that get to the young seeds by eating into the fruit while it is still immature on the tree (Haber and Frankie 1983). Germination occurs after the wet season begins with the first rain (Frankie et al. 1974). Tapirs, howler monkeys, and various moth larvae eat the leaves of L. candida (Haber and Frankie 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Culicoides is a genus of insect of the order Diptera. They are commonly known as biting midges or no-see-ums due to their small size. They are holometabolous, which means they progress from egg, to larva, to pupa, to adults (Hogue 1983). Adults are usually 1 to 2.5 mm long (Rolston and Johnson 2012). The larvae are slender and wormlike with a yellow to brown head and a translucent white body and are usually 2-5 mm long (Hogue 1983). Pupae are morphologically similar to those found in Dipteran suborder Nematocera (Blanton and Wirth 1979). Adults have large compound eyes, antennae with 15 divisions, and well-developed mouth parts. Males and females are similar with a few differences. Both genders have wings with patterns of dark and light spots, which is useful for species classification. The mouth parts of both males and females are well-developed and are often as long as the head capsule. Female mouth parts are more developed, and are adapted for piercing and blood-sucking. Males have longer and narrower wings compared to females with less contrasting color patterns and a slender abdomen with prominent terminal genitalia. Females have a stout abdomen with a tapered apex. Mating generally takes place in flight. Males swarm and females fly through the swarm and are captured by the males (Blanton and Wirth1979).

The genus has a cosmopolitan distribution. They breed in coastal marshes and swamps. In most species, the larvae require areas of waterlogged sand mixed with humus above high tides (Hogue 1983). In many species, the larvae are not strictly aquatic or terrestrial, and simply need air, water, and food. They cannot, however, survive without moisture. Some larvae are able to develop in moist manure-contaminated areas (Mullen 2002).

Females are anautogenous , which means a blood meal is needed for egg maturation. Therefore only females suck blood. The larvae eat organic detritus, yeasts, and algae (Hogue 1983). Adult males eat nectar and females may increase longevity by doing so. While most species need a blood meal for egg maturation, some species can lay eggs the first time without a blood meal using reserves stored during the larval stage. However, they need a blood meal for subsequent egg maturation (Blanton and Wirth 1979). Females can lay up to 400 eggs (Rolston and Johnson 2012).

Little is known about the natural enemies of Culicoides, but annelid worms have been known to feed upon larvae. Larger flies have been observed preying upon adults. There are susceptible to several types of viruses and bacteria. Mermithid worms are also common parasites of Culicoides throughout the world. Adults are also known to be parasitized by larval mites and are preyed upon by larvae of the mosquito Anopheles barberi (Blanton and Wirth 1979).

While most species are simply a nuisance, an increasing number of species have been found to be vectors of pathogens to man and animals. In Central and South America, along with some Caribbean islands and parts of Africa, some species are vectors of filarial worms, which can cause dermatitis and skin lesions in humans (Eldridge and Edman 2000). They are also known to transmit the bluetounge virus, which is pathogenic to sheep and to cattle, and has resulted in heavy losses of sheep. This virus is known to occur in Western North America, Asia, and Africa. They can also transmit the African Horsesickness virus in equines, which is found in Africa, and the Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease virus in ruminants, which is found in North America (Blanton and Wirth 1979).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Auricularia delicata is one of eight members of its genus that share a widespread distribution (Ainsworth 2008). However, the family Auriculariaceae on the whole has around 100 species worldwide and were formerly classified as "heterobasidiomycetes" due to their gelatinous basidiocarps on septate basidia (Ainsworth 2008). The spore-producing cells, called basidia, are divided (septate) transversely and belong to a larger group of fungi that share similar traits, like Tremella mesenterica, Tremiscus helvelloides, and Calcera viscosa (Kibby 1992). Recent phylogenetic studies say that the genus is closely related to the family Exidiaceae (Ainsworth 2008).

A. delicata has a gelatinous ear-shaped fruitbody that gives it its common name "Jelly Fungus". The fruitbody is the name given to the spore-producing organ of a fungus. It is typically 0.5 to 4.5 cm long and 2.0 to 6.5 cm wide (Mata Hidalgo 2003). However, some sources say that it can get as large as 9.0 cm. The non-fertile surface is velvety and finely wrinkled with a light brown to reddish brown color. The context is 0.1 to 0.2 cm wide and has the same color as the non-fertile surface. It has a pleasant odor and is slightly sweet tasting. Some individuals have stated that they even have used it to stop bleeding (Sarma et al. 2010). The hymenium—a surface on the fungi that has spore-bearing structures—has extremely prominent reticulations that are white to yellowish-beige to pale brownish-beige. It is laterally attached to the substrate at this point. A. delicata is gregarious and grows on fallen tree trunks and branches, or occasionally on moss growing on living trees (Mata Hidalgo 2003).

The sexual reproduction consists in the formation of the club-shaped end cells (basidia). These structures produce specialized spores called basidiospores that are typically fordibly discharged—giving them the name ballistospores (Pringle et al. 2005). When they land in a suitable substrate, the spores will form hyphae that come together as mycelia to form the fruitbody and start the cycle again.

A. delicata can be found from May to January, but dehydrated fruitbodies may still be found throughout the dry season. Upon receiving moisture, it will regain its gelatinous consistency (Mata Hildago 2003). When dry, the fruitbody is thin with a translucent to opaque color. It is typically brittle in this stage and will therefore break easily (Lowy 1952). The fruitbody is possibly edible and temperate zone species of Auricularia are eaten throughout most of Asia (Mata Hidalgo 2003). It has a tropical distribution, stretching from Mexico to Ecuador and the West Indies. A. delicata can be easily identified in the field by its gelatinous fruitbody and wrinkled or reticulate fertile surface. This net-like underside is a characteristic that separates this species from others in the Auricularia genus (Mata Hidalgo 2003).

Auricularia delicata

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Myrmecophila christinae (synonyms M. tibicinis, Schomburkia tibicinis) is an epiphytic orchid found in the coastal lowlands of the Neotropics (Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011). It is found on trees and shrubs, but can also grow terrestrially in dune habitat (Rico-Gray and Thien 1989). Like many other orchids, it exhibits a deceit pollination strategy (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). M. christinae is often host to several ant species, which live in its large pseudobulbs and feed on its extra floral nectaries (Rico-Gary and Thien 1989).

The taxonomic status of this organism is still being determined (Carnevali et. al. 2003). M. christinae and M. tibicinis are often considered as one species, apparently due to difficulties in differentiating between the two (Carnevali et al. 2003, Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). However, it is believed that these species, along with two others in Myrmecophila, have experienced a very recent speciation event (Carnevali et. al. 2003).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description:
Xylocopa spp., Eulaema polychroma - pollinators

Camponotus spp., Ectatomma tuberculatum - symbionts

Stethobaris sp. - predator

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Behaviour
dataObject.dc:description:
The extra-floral nectaries of M. christinae usually attract nectarivorous carpenter ants (Camponotus sp.) at the onset of warm weather, as well as Ectatomma tuberculatum, which arrives later and takes over (Malo et. al. 2001, Rico-Gray and Thien 1989). Multiple ant species can inhabit the same plant, but territoriality keeps each colony confined to its own pseudobulb (Rico-Gray and Thien 1989). They protect the plant from herbivores like the flower weevil Stethobaris (which kills spikes and flowers) in return for protection and housing in the modified psuedobulb (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). E. tuberculatum exhibits the best protective abilities due to its larger size, and smaller ants may not offer any significant protection from Stethobaris (Rico-Gray and Thien 1989).

While M. christinae may receive nutrients from ant psuedobulb activity, the ratio of nectar feeding to folivore/herbivore protection may not always benefit the plant (Gegenbauer et. al. 2012, Rico-Gray and Thien 1989). Thus, the status of this plant-animal relationship remains undetermined, as it is likely dynamic and unique to each plant.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: M. tibicinis (formerly Schomburgkia tibicinis) - no differentiating characteristics known.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description: M. christinae typically has two long inflorescences, producing 6-15 self-compatible, large, yellow to purple flowers that last about a week (Malo et. al. 2001, Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011, Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description:
Pollination is achieved through carpenter bees (Xylocopa sp.) and the euglossine bee Eulaema polychroma (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). Each flower has 8 pollinia, one or all of which can be removed in a single visit with the removal of the entire pollinarium (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). The pollinia are attached to the thorax of bees leaving the flower, which enter after attraction by the flower’s scent (Malo et. al. 2001, Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011). Like many deceit orchids, pollination rates are low, with only 2-30% of plants fruiting in a given year (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). Furthermore, the available time frame for pollination is very small, as bees are only present at flowers for around 2 seconds (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). M. christinae seeds are wind dispersed, with hundreds of thousands of seeds from a single capsule (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004).

Pollinator attractants include scents and its broad floral display (Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011). M. christinae follows a non-synchronous flowering phenology, with early (March/April) and late (June) flowering plants experiencing a higher likelihood of pollinium (pollen packet) removal (Parra-Tabla and Vargas 2004). This negative dependency selection is due to its deceit pollination strategy, and may also be caused by a severe lack of pollinators (Parra-Table and Vargas 2004). Thus, the attraction mechanisms of M. christinae of floral display and scent are highly important for pollination (Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObject.dc:description: M. christinae is experiencing population declines due to human expansion and dune habitat fragmentation (Parra-Tabla et. al. 2011). Populations in small habitat fragments (<1 hectare) experience fewer seedlings and reduced fruiting (Parra-Table et. al. 2011).

taxon.reference: Haehner, R. 2006. Columnea consanguinea. In: Gesneriads of Costa Rica, D.A. Solera, ed. Instituto Nacional de Biodiversidad, Costa Rica, pp. 128-129.

Morley, B.D. 1974. Notes on some critical characters in Columnea classification. Annals of the Missouri Botanical Garden 61(2): 514-525.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Columnea consanguinea, sometimes referred to as “the Blood of Christ” (Wong & Srivastava 2010), is a Neotropical epiphyte, rarely a terrestrial shrub in the Gesneriaceae. The stems of the plant are usually found in an upward inclined position to allow light to hit the leaves at an optimal position. The leaves of the plant average 16.5 centimeters long and 5.5 centimeters wide. However, the leaf size and shape can vary greatly. The most interesting feature to the leaves are the red blotches. These blotches are found on the underside of the leaves towards the tip of the leaves and have a corresponding yellow-green blotch on the upper part of the leaves. These blotches can vary in number and size, from 1-4 spots per leaf, 1-5 cm in diameter (Haehner, 2006). Since the spots are somewhat translucent on the upper surface, light passes through the top, causing a red “stained glass” effect.

It has been suggested that the red spots are to attract hummingbirds to its inconspicuous yellow flowers beneath leaves, but this has yet to be demonstrated (Morley 1974). According to Wong & Srivastava (2010), the red blotches on the leaves reduce herbivory by about 70%.

Columnea consanguinea has many yellow, tubular flowers that are found underneath the leaves and very close to the stem. In some cases, the flowers also have a little red on the lobes. The corolla averages at about 2.3 centimeters. The sepals of the flowers are usually all green, but can also be found with red spots or in rare cases completely red. They also are slightly fuzzy. The bracts of the flowers are about 2.2 centimeters long. (Haehner, 2006). The fruit produced by the plant is a small, yellow berry that is also slightly hairy. These flowers and fruits can be found year-round. The flowers of C. consanguinea are shaped similar to that of C. decapleura, which are hummingbird pollinated, suggesting that C. consanguinea are also hummingbird pollinated (Martin-Rodriguez et. al., 2009). However, since the flowers are inconspicuous, it has been said that the red spots are used to attract the hummingbirds to the plant (Morley 1974).

Morley (1973) found that in Panama the C. consanguinea had small hairs on the leaves that were closer to the leaf than the hairs on the Costa Rican variety that were more erect. He also found that the leaves on C. consanguinea darienensis variety have not been found with the signature red leaf spots. Currently, the variation in the plants is considered just a different variety, but may soon be seen as a different species.

Columnea consanguinea can be found from Nicaragua to Colombia and Ecuador. In Costa Rica, it is found in very humid areas in the main mountain ranges from 300 meters to 2000 meters on the Atlantic slope (Haehner, 2006) and just over the divide.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description: It has been suggested that the red spots on the underside of the leaves are to attract hummingbirds to the small, inconspicuous yellow flowers underneath leaves (Morley 1974). Comparing the flowers to that of other Columnea sp., it has been suggested that C. consanguinea are hummingbird pollinated (Martin-Rodriguez et. al., 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Columnea consanguinea can be found from Nicaragua to Colombia and Ecuador. In Costa Rica, it is found only on the Atlantic slope of the main mountin ranges (Haehner, 2006).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Columnea consanguinea is an epiphytic plant, but can sometimes be found as a terrestrial plant as well. In Costa Rica, it is found in very humid tropical forests in the main mountain ranges from 300 meters to 2000 meters on the Atlantic slope (Haehner, 2006).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Dipteryx panamensis (also known as the Almendro tree) is a large tree endemic to Southern Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama and Colombia. It grows mainly in the lowlands on the Atlantic coast, preferring alluvial or sandy soils. It is abundant in humid tropical forests, with temperature from 24-30ºC and annual rainfall from 3.5-5.5m (Fournier 2003). It is a tetraploid species, and shows much genetic diversity between trees (Hanson 2008).

It is an emergent canopy tree that grows from 15-50m in height with 1-1.6 m in diameter at breast hight (DBH). The bark is a gray-red-brown with vertical lenticles. Flowers are pink or purple and grouped in terminal or lateral panicles that are 30-50 cm in length. Flowers grow above the foliage and are conspicuous from a distance (Condit et al. 2011). D. panamensis flowers at the start of the rainy season, and is thus slightly variable by location, but usually begins in early May (Fournier 2003). Flowers give off a strong, sweet-pea like odor, and are pollinated by medium to large bees (Perry & Starrett 1980).

Leaves are alternate and imparipinnately compound, with 11-13 leaflets that alternate along the rachis (Condit et al, 2011). The rachis is slightly winged, and often extends beyond the leaflets. Leaflets are asymmetric, with the leading half wider than the trailing half. Both sides of leaflets are nearly glaborous (Fournier, 2003).

Fruits are indehiscent, ellipsoid pods that are 6-8cm long, 4-5cm wide, and 2-3cm thick (Gentry et al. 1996, Fournier 2003). They have a single hard seed surrounded by a thin layer of brown pulp. These seeds are a staple for local mammal populations, with agoutis frequently seen gnawing on them. Most seeds found on the ground are missing their sweet pulp layer (Condit et al. 2011). Bats are an important disperser, carrying the fruit off to eat the sweet pulp, but leaving the seed intact. Fruits develop over a period of about 4 months, usually during a dry period. They frequently bear exocarpic scars from insects that oviposit in the immature fruit (Fournier 2003).

A slow growing tree, its wood is extremely dense, with a specific gravity of .83 to 1.09 (Fournier 2003). The wood is so dense that it was difficult to harvest until the mid-1980's, when chainsaw technology had sufficiently improved. Now, the durable wood is particularly used for railroad ties, marine construction, and bridges. Its high mechanical resistance makes it valuable for use in industrial construction (Sanchez).

D. panamensis is particularly associated with the Great Green Macaw (Ara ambiguus), an endangered species of parrot. The tall emergent trees provide shelter for the birds, who nest in hollows created by dead branches. The seed is also frequently predated upon by the Great Green Macaw, whose beak is strong enough to penetrate the hard and fibrous mesocarp to reach the seed. Harvesting of Dipteryx panamensis is contributing to the habitat loss that is endangering the Great Green Macaw. (Hanson 2008, Chassot & Monge 2012)

taxon.reference: Gargiullo, M.B. (2008). A Field Guide to Plants of Costa Rica. San José, Costa Rica: Zona Tropical Publications.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: The Acnistus arborescens belongs to the family Solanaceae. A shrub or small tree, this species can grow anywhere from 2-10 meters tall. They are usually multistemmed with pale tan bark that is very corky, spongy, and deeply grooved. Trees in this species are easily colonized by epiphytes due to the corky bark, which serves as an ideal substrate for orchids (Haber et al. 2000). The deeply fissured bark that runs longitudinal on the trunk is a defining characteristic of this species, as well as the typical presence of galls (warty appearance) on the leaves. The leaves can grow 5-20 cm long and 3-14 cm wide, having a narrow ellyptic shape with the tip and base pointed (Gargiullo 2008). Small white flowers 1 cm long are radially symmetrical, tubular, bell-shaped and grow in clusters of around 30 on the stems below leaves. Blooming from May - Sept these fragrant flowers are diurnal and attract an array of mostly insect pollinators that include bees, butterflies, wasps, beetles, flies, and occasionally hummingbirds (Haber et al. 2000). After successful pollination, fleshy fruits develop that are small, round, and orange when ripe. The fruits are 0.5-1 cm wide. Fruits are commonly eaten by birds that serve as dispersers for the tiny flat seeds, though bats have also been found to eat them during the fruiting period of July-October (Howell and Burch 1974, Gargiullo 2008). The trees grow in second or open growth areas between 600 and 1500 meters of elevation above sea level. Distribution stretches from Mexico to South America and the West Indies. Found in open areas such as road sides and pastures, it commonly serves as a living fence post (Zuchowski 2007). Medicinal uses have been found for this plant to include teas for sore throat and coughs, and may contain anticancer properties (Zuchowski 2007, Gargiullo 2008).

taxon.reference: Bandarra, P. M., S. P. Pavarini, D. L. Raymundo, A. M. Correa, P. M. Pedroso, and D. Driemeier. Trema micrantha toxicity in horses in Brazil. National Center for Biotechnology Information. U.S. National Library of Medicine, July 2010. Web. 20 Apr. 2014.
Gargiullo, M., B. Magnuson, and L. Kimball (2008). A Field Guide to Plants of Costa Rica. Zona Tropical Publications, Oxford University Press: China. 131
Hartshorn, G.S. (1983). Trema micrantha. Costa Rican Natural History. Ed. Daniel H. Janzen. University of Chicago Press: Chicago, IL. 337 – 338
Zuchowski, W. (2007). Tropical Plants of Costa Rica. Zona Tropical Publications, Cornell University Press: China. 70 - 71

Gómez-Pompa, A. and C. Vázquez-Yanes (1981). Successional studies of a rainforest of Mexico. In: West DC, Shugart HH and Botking DH (eds) Forest Succession, Concepts and Applications. Springer Verlag, New York 246 - 266

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: The Jamaican Nettletree (Trema micrantha) is one of the few neotropical members of the largely temperate Ulmaceae family (sometimes placed in the Cannabaceae family). Trema micrantha is a fast-growing, small to medium sized ruderal tree that is well adapted to live in chronically disturbed areas (Zuchowski 2007). It is found from Mexico to Argentina up to 2100m in elevation as well as in parts of southern Florida and the West Indies (Zuchowski 2007).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description:
The strong, fibrous bark of Trema micrantha houses caterpillars of epialid moths (Zuchowksi 2007). Humans frequently use this bark to make rope (Zuchowski 2007).

Ingestion of Trema micrantha leaves has been documented to lead to fatal toxicity in horses (Bandarra et al. 2010).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Leaves are distichous, simple, alternate, with stipules, and reach up to 15 cm long (Gargiullo et al. 2008). Margins are serrate and the base is usually not equilateral (Hartshorn 1983). Additionally, leaves have a rough-textured upper surface and are covered in stiff grey hairs (Gargiullo et al. 2008).

Flowers are tiny, white-greenish inflorescences (Gargiullo et al. 2008). Flowers are single sex but trees are monoecoius (Zuchowski 2007), meaning that both male and female flowers can be found on the same plant. Fruits are small orange or red drupes up to 2mm long (Hartshorn 1983).

Mature trees are characterized by slight buttresses and lightly fissured bark (Hartshorn 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Dispersal
dataObject.dc:description: Trema micrantha produces fruits throughout the year (Zuchowski 2007). Because fruits of various stages are clumped together, the fruit-laden branches display a mix of green, yellow, orange, and red. These fruits attract a variety of frugivorous birds that eat the fruits and act as seed dispersers (Zuchowski 2007).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Trema micrantha is present from Mexico to Argentina as well as in parts of southern Florida and the West Indies (Zuchowski 2007).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Growth
dataObject.dc:description: As a pioneer species, Trema micrantha is capable of growing very quickly at a rate of 13.5m per year.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Trema micrantha can be found in both wet and seasonally dry habitats, up to 2100m in elevation. It is a pioneer species that frequents chronically disturbed, second-growth areas, such as old pastures and along river banks (Zuchowski 2007). As a ruderal species, its seeds are thought to have long soil dormancy (Hartshorn 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeExpectancy
dataObject.dc:description: In secondary forests the life span of Trema micrantha is somewhat short; after about 30 years it is usually replaced by longer living mature forest trees (Gómez-Pompa and Vázquez-Yanes 1981).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: Trema micrantha flowers throughout the year (Zuchowski 2007). Its flowers are primarily pollinated by small insects but may also undergo wind pollination, as well (Zuchowski 2007).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObject.dc:description: Though commonly found in its shrub form, Trema micrantha is capable of growing up to 30m tall and 70 cm in diameter (Gargiullo et al. 2008)

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Bonellia nervosa, formerly Jacquinia pungens, is an understory shrub in the family Primulaceae, formerly Theophrastaceae (Janzen 1983). It is found in deciduous and semi-deciduous forests on the Pacific Coast of Meso- and Central America, from Jalisco, Mexico to Northwestern Costa Rica (Chaves & Avalos 2008). This species does not grow over 5 meters tall. It has alternate, simple leaves with needle-sharp tips (Zuchowski 2007). The leaves are very bitter (Janzen 1983) and contain saponins and alkaloids (Zuchowski 2007). They also contain jacquinonic acid, an ant-repellent compound (Okunade 1985), and are used as a fish poison in Mexico (Janzen 1970). B. nervosa produces leaves and flowers in the dry season, when most other trees and shrubs are leafless, and is dormant and leafless in the rainy season (Janzen 1983, Chaves & Avalos 2008). This inverse leaf phenology allows B. nervosa to take advantage of the sunlight in the understory (Zuchowski 2007). Despite being one of the only green plants during the dry season in deciduous forests, B. nervosa is not known to have many herbivorous predators, likely due to its bitter taste and chemical protection (Janzen 1970). Branch elongation occurs at the time of leaf production (Janzen 1970). B. nervosa is able to have leaves and flowers in the dry season due to its deep taproot that extends down 0.5 to 1.5 meters. This allows it to reach water unavailable to most other plants (Janzen 1970). B. nervosa has no lateral roots in the upper soil level. (Janzen 1970).

B. nervosa flowers within two months of leaf production (Janzen 1970). Its flowers are tubular and orange/red in color (Janzen 1983). When a flower first opens, its anthers cover the stigma. A few days later, the anthers split to expose the stigma and pollination can occur (Janzen 1983). The pollinator of these flowers is unknown, with hummingbirds (Janzen 1970) and small insects (Zuchowski 2007) being primary contenders. The small spherical fruits of B. nervosa appear shortly after pollination and are extremely bitter until they ripen in the middle of the rainy season (Janzen 1983, 1970). The fruits have a hard rind and juicy flesh. They attract and are dispersed by birds or mammals (Janzen 1983). Mammalian seed predators have refused to eat B nervosa seeds under experimental conditions, and there is very little seed predation (Janzen 1970).

taxon.reference: Hartshorn, G.S. 1983. Virola sebifera (Fruta Dorada, Wild Nutmeg) in Costa Rican Natural History. Ed. Daniel H. Janzen. Chicago, US. p. 345-346.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Virola sebifera is part of the pan-tropical Myristicaceae family. The genus Virola is neo-tropical and the species V. sebifera has a specific range of Bolivia to Southern Brazil and Nicaragua, the largest of the five total Neotropical genera. It is frequently found in evergreen forests, savannas, as well as tropical moist, wet, pre-montane wet and rain life zones. It typically occurs from sea level up to 1400 meters in altitude (Leigh 1999).

V. sebifera is a mid-story to canopy tree that can reach up to 40 meters in height and 80 cm dbh, with slight buttresses. V. sebifera has a wood density of about 0.37 g/cm³. Its small branches are unique to all Neotropical Myristicaceae, coming out of the trunk horizontally at 90-degree angles in whorled rings around the trunk. The trunk and branches are coved by a thick, brown reticular bark. In the inner bark, the tree has a watery, red sap. (Hartshorn 1983, Leigh 1999).

Twigs and leaves of the tree have an abundant rust, golden pubescence. Leaves are distichously arranged along the twigs. The leaves are simple, alternate formation with no stipules and evenly spaced parallel secondary leaf venation (an average of less than 1 per centimeter along the midrib). Individual leaves can grow up to 30 cm in length. Leaves are widest no more than halfway from the base to the tip. Sapling leaves have a soft, velvety texture on the underside. Individual trees are dioecious, having very small yellow flowers that grow in panicles. Flowers bloom from roughly December to March (according to studies in La Selva, Costa Rica) and are pollinated by small bees, wasps and flies. (Hartshorn 1983).

Its fruits mature in June to October and continue into February. Fruits are bivalve dehiscent, brown capsules approximately 8-10cm long, containing a single yellow, green seed covered by a bright red lacinate aril. Seeds are dispersed by approximately 7 species of medium to large sized frugivorous birds, 49 percent of its dispersers being Toucans, specifically Chesnut-Mandibled Toucans (Howe 1981). These birds will take the seed out of the partially opened capsule and swallow it whole. Most species will remove and digest the red aril in the crop and regurgitate the seed or others will occasionally pass the whole seed to disperse. Seeds are shade tolerant but respond vigorously to canopy openings and forest light gaps. Saplings will arrange their leaves in their top layer so as to absorb as much of the light specs coming through the canopy without shading itself.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Dieffenbachia is a genus of the family Araceae and the subfamily Philodendroideae, closely related to the genus Philodendron (Croat 1983). It consists of 30 species of monocot angiosperms that are native to the tropics, thriving in hot, humid places, though it also has a positive response to drier conditions as well. Its tolerance to shade has made it a popular houseplant, and thus is commercially cultivated and distributed in residences all over the world (Hill 2014). Dieffenbachia are characteristic in their aroid, large leaves with cream-colored margins and venation and green spotting (Encyclopaedia Britannica 2013, Croat 1983). They also exhibit a unique mutualism with scarab beetle pollinators, which depend on their club-shaped inflorescent spadix, kettle-shaped, convolute spathe, and the aroma emitted by the spadix's thermogenetic behavior (Croat 1983). They can range from 96 to 180 cm tall (Hill 2014). Dieffenbachia are toxic plants, especially in their calcium-oxalate-enriched sap in their stems. The calcium oxalate is in the form of long crystals that penetrate living tissues and cause a variety of toxic reactions such as inflammation of the mucous membranes, irritation, excessive salivation, and cell death (Encyclopaedia Britannica 2013, Hill 2014, Botanical Online 2014). Because they are commonly kept as houseplants, they are widely cautioned against by a number of human pet organizations.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Biology
dataObject.dc:description: Dieffenbachia are poisonous, especially their stems. They are called dumbcane for the numbing effect they exude on predators that chew on its stems. This effect is caused by a combination of chemicals and reactions in the toxic sap, including calcium oxalate, proteolytic enzyme (called "dumbcain" after this plant), and asparagine. Together with calcium, the calcium-oxalate of the sap can facilitate the formation of kidney stones (Botanical Online 2014). Ingestion can cause symptoms that last for many days up to a couple of weeks, including rapid irritation of the mucous membranes, burning, excessive salivation from kinins, swelling of the tongue and lips, cell necrosis, and interrupting normal swallowing and breathing (Encyclopaedia Britannica 2013, Hill 2014).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObject.dc:description:
Dieffenbachia as houseplants rarely obtain diseases. In the wild, they can be infested by mealybugs and aphids that suck plant juices and heavy infestations that coat the leaves of Dieffenbachia with sticky honeydew. Symptoms of malnutrition include yellow, smaller leaves and stunted growth (Norman 2011).

The commercial production of Dieffenbachia can house rampant bacterial and fungal diseases (Norman 2011).

Common bacterial diseases include Erwinia Blight/Soft Rot and Xanthomonas Leaf Spot, named after their respective bacterial species causing the disease. Symptoms for the former include yellow leaves and mushy spots that sometimes fall out and emit a rotten fishy smell, usually occurring during warm summer months in hot, high humidity. It can be controlled using copper and mancozeb-containing chemicals. Xanthomonas Leaf Spot-affected plants exhibit dark, black spots surrounded by a yellow halo and collapsed affected leaves. It is easily transmittable from plant to plant through moisture exchange and is aided by poor nutrition. Chemical compounds containing copper or Bacilius subtilis can be utilized to control the bacteria (Norman 2011).

Common fungal diseases include Fusarium stem rot, Anthracnose Leaf Spot, Myrothecium Leaf Spot and Petiole Rot, and Phytophtora Stem and Root Rot and Leaf Spot. Fusarium fungi cause mushy stem growth, papery blackened leaves, and reddish or purple discoloration in the affected area, usually caused by propagation in greenhouses, beginning with contaminated soil. Anthranose Leaf Spot is caused by Colletotrichum gloeosporioides. Affected plants exhibit beige, water-soaked spots with yellow halos as well as black specks in concentric rings within the spot, which are the spores of the fungus. It is usually observed after fertilizer or pesticide damage in condensation-packed areas. Myrothecium fungi cause petiole rot and leaf spots in wounded leaves. On the underside are black and white spores and fungal fruiting bodies. New leaves are the most vulnerable. Phytophora fungi infect the roots, which consequently turn brown. All fungal infections can be controlled with fungicides (Norman 2011).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: Native to American tropics, Dieffenbachia spp. is a favorite houseplant, so it can be found indoors anywhere in the world (Hill 2014). They are usually present as understory herbs in moist or wet life zones, including premontane and tropical rainforest (Young 1986). Found anywhere from 0 to 1500 m in elevation, in neo to sub-tropical regions (Hammel 2003).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
They have simple, alternate, entire-veined, large oblong leaves without stipules, usually characterized by mottled white, yellowish colors marking the veins and different shades of green spotting the leaves (Hill 2014). Popular colorful houseplant varieties include D. maculata, D. picta, D. seguine, and D. amoena, which all display large, variegated leaves with a creamy color marking veins, bordered by green; plants can be up to 180 cm tall (6 feet) with 50 cm long leaves (20 in.). Like all Araceae plants, their flowers are in the form of spadix surrounded by a spathe: the inflorescenced spadix contains both female and male flowers (unisexual), separated by a row of sterile flowers, where the spathe also enfolds, forming a kettle-like chamber for the lower pistillate flowers. Pistillate (female) flowers are on the bottom, carpellate males on the top. Once pollinated primarily by scarab beetles, they produce bright-red or red-orange berries (Encyclopaedia Britannica 2014, Hill 2014). Their stems are stout, succulent and green and emit a submilky, often foul and skunk-smelling sap. They are marked with leaf scars and have sheathing petioles. Although Dieffenbachia are monocots, they have netlike wing venation (Hill 2014).

Characteristics of popular house-grown varieties are described here (Russ and Pertuit 1999):

-'Tropic Snow' Dieffenbachia amoena have wide, dark green leaves blotched in creamy white along the veins. Compared to most other dieffenbachia, they can tolerate lower light levels.

-'Camille' cultivar Dieffenbachia maculate “Camille” have creamy yellow leaves bounded in green. It is busy and lush.

-'Compacta' Dieffenbachia compacta is a compact-growing species with cream colored leaves mottled with bright green.

-'Tiki' cultivar of Dieffenbachia maculata is one of the largest dieffenbachias at maturity. It can tolerate low light levels. Its silver leaves are mottled with green and white.

-'Rudolph Roehrs' cultivar of Dieffenbachia maculata has creamy yellow leaves with white spots and dark green margins.

-'Hilo' Dieffenbachia “Hilo” is large-leafed with pointed leaves and prominent white veins.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Growth
dataObject.dc:description: Large aroid leaves typically grow on the top of this understory plant, clustered (Croat 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Species in this genus thrive in hot, humid temperatures and moist or wet life zones (Croat 1983). However, they also respond well to drier climates (Hill 2014). They are also shade tolerant and filtered light through a window is sufficient for successful growth. Their soils need to be moderately moist, but well-drained, acidic, alkaline, or neutral, and sandy clay loam. If grown in temperate areas, they must be grown indoors in loamy soil under bright filtered light and moderate watering (RHS Plant Selector 2013).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObject.dc:description: Dieffenbachia follows the typical angiosperm-monocot life cycle (alternation of generations, dominant 2n sporophyte); however, its spathe and spadix structure allows for specialized mutualism with scarab beetle pollinators. It lobed or kettle-shaped spathe divides the spadix inflorescence into two sections with carpellate flowers residing on the top and pistillate flowers enveloped by the kettle on the bottom. The beetles, upon entering the flower, already carry pollen from other Dieffenbachia individuals. During daytime, only the male flowers open, allowing the beetles to feed on them. Come nightfall, the lobe on the spathe relaxes only for a moment, which allows the beetles to move into the kettle, where all the female flowers, now open, reside. The beetles mate and pollinate the female flowers while feeding on the row of sterile flowers that conjunct the divide between the male and female flowers, located right at the convolute lobe (Croat 1983). When morning arrive, the spathe opens again, allowing the beetles to exit. On the way out, they step on the opened male flowers, carrying new pollen with them to the next flower they will pollinate. Pollinated female flowers produce fruits, at which point the spathe withers and falls in order to expose the mammal-dispersed berries (Croat 1983, Boyce and Yeng 2013).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LookAlikes
dataObject.dc:description: Other common houseplants such as Aglacnema (Chinese evergreen) and Spathiphyllum (peace lilies) can be confused with Dieffenbachia. Differentiating characteristics include inequilateral leaf bases and more separated spadix and spathe in Aglacnema. Spathiphyllum has clustered leaves that do not originate from a stout stem unlike Dieffenbachia (Hill 2014).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObject.dc:description: Size depends on the species of the genus. Most sizes range from 96 cm (3 ft) to 180 cm (6 ft) and 30.5 cm (1 ft) to 90 cm (3 ft) wide and leaves can be up to 45.72 cm (18 in) long by 30.45 cm (12 in) wide. A maximum size has been found to be 2.5 m (Russ and Pertuit 1999, Botanical Online 2013).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: Dieffenbachia have recently been studied for its antiangiogenetic properties. Antiangiogenesis is a cancer-combating process that inhibits the growth of new blood vessels in the body and the growth of new cancerous tumors. Scientists have successfully found that certain chemicals in Dieffenbachia can prevent blood vessel development and growth, which makes it a strong contender for anti-cancer drugs (Agron 2013).

taxon.reference: Hanson, P.E. & I.D. Gauld. 1995 The Bees (Apidae). In The Hymenoptera of Costa Rica, ed P.E. Hanson & I.D. Gauld, pp 651-691 Oxford: Oxford University Press.
Otis, G. W., R.J. McGinley, L. Garling, & L. Malaret. 1982. Biology and systematics of the bee genus Crawfordapis (Colletidae, Diphaglossinae). Psyche, 89(3-4), 279-296.
Roubik, D. W., & C.D. Michener. 1984. Nesting biology of Crawfordapis in Panama (Hymenoptera, Colletidae). Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society, 662-671.
Roubik, D.W. 1989. Ecology and Natural History of Tropical Bees. New York City, New York: Cambridge University Press.
Wuellner, C. T., & Y. Jang. 1996. Natural history of a ground-nesting solitary bee, Crawfordapis luctuosa (Hymenoptera: Colletidae). Journal of the Kansas Entomological Society, 211-221.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Crawfordapis luctuosa is a dark sable colored, hairy, short-tongued bee with dark wings (Wuellner & Jang 1996). C. luctuosa is large and robust, usually measuring around 24 mm, and can be characterized by the elongated first flagellar segment of its antennae and a complete pre-episternal groove located on its thorax (Otis et. al 1982). It is generally considered a non-social or solitary bee, but nests in aggregations, as do all other bees in the family Colletidae (Wuellner & Jang 1996). Since these bees are solitary every individual has the ability to reproduce. Birds and army ants are C. luctuosa’s main predators. This particular bee belongs to the subfamily Diphaglossinae, which is restricted to the New World (Hanson & Gauld 1995).

This species is found from the state of Chiapas in Southern Mexico to Western Panama between 1500m and 1880m in elevation. (Hanson Gauld 1995, Roubik & Michener 1984, Roubik 1989, Wuellner & Jang 1996). C. luctuosa construct underground nests in disturbed/exposed areas. Landslide areas are regularly used, but with the increase in human disturbances these nests are now more commonly found in chronically disturbed areas such as soft soils next to roads (Hanson & Gauld 1989). These nests are approximately 50 cm in length and start as tubes that open into a spherical chamber and terminate in ending cells that hold larvae and/or eggs (Wuellner & Jang 1996).

While adults do not feed, the females still collect pollen and nectar from buzz-pollinated plants of the Melastomataceae, Sapotaceae, Solanaceae, and Begoniaceae families to feed their larvae and eggs (Roubik & Michener 1984, Wuellner & Jang 1996). Males never enter the nests, but they do hover around the aggregations and often attempt copulation with passing females. The males do not appear to be territorial (Otis et. al 1982).

While these bees are generally considered solitary some researchers have observed females visiting multiples nests per day or more than one female occupying a single nest, however, no study has gathered sufficient data to determine the level of sociality, if any, exists (Otis et. al 1982, Wuellner & Jang 1996). Roubik and Michener (1984) speculated that these female interactions could possibly be cleptoparasitism of pollen, but this study also lacked enough data to determine the validity of this hypothesis.

taxon.reference: Colwell, R.K. 1979. The geographical ecology of hummingbird mites in relation to their host plants and cariers. Recent Advances in Acarology 2: 461-468

Colwell, R.K. 1983. “Rhinoseius colwelli (Ácaro Floral del Colibrí, Totolate Floral de Colibrí, Hummingbird Flower Mite)". In Janzen, D.H.. Costa Rican Natural History. Ed. Daniel H. Janzen. Chicago London: University of Chicago Press. 767-768. Print.
Colwell, R. K. 1985. Stowaways on the hummingbird express. Natural History 94:56- 63.
Diamond, J. and T.J. Case. 1985. Community biology and sexual selection: lessons from hummingbird flower mites. Community Ecology: 406-424.

Heyneman, A.J., R.K. Colwell, S. Naeem, D.S. Dobkin, B. Hallet. 1991. Host Plant Discrimination: Experiments with Hummingbird Flower Mites. Plant-Animal Interactions: Ecolutionary Ecology in Tropical and Temperate Regions.

Lara, C. and Orneals, J.F. 2002. Effects of nectar theft by flower mites on hummingbird behavior and the reproductive success of their host plant, Moussonia deppeana (Gesneriaceae). Okios 96: 470-480.
