dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Hummingbird Flower Mites (genus Rhinoseius, order Mesostigmata: Ascidae) spend most of their lives in the inflorescences of hummingbird-pollinated plants (Diamond and Case, 1985). The genus Rhinoseius is the most diverse of the three ascid genera inhibiting hummingbird-pollinated flowers. The genus currently contains 34 different species. These mites can grow up to 0.6 mm long and are identified by their whitish coloration. For their size they can run as fast as a cheetah (Colwell, 1983). Rhinoseius mites (both sexes) are exhibit a cheliceral fixed digit without teeth except at apex, and a dorsal shield lacking a setal pair (Oconnor et al. 1997).

Hummingbird mites are reliant on a year round supply of flowers. They feed on nectar and pollen, mate, and lay eggs near or inside the corollas of ornithophilous flowers (meaning they are pollinated by birds) (Heyneman et al. 1991). In order to migrate from plant-to-plant these mites are dependent on the mutualisms between hummingbirds and hummingbird-pollinated plants (Diamond and Case, 1995). This relationship, known as a phoretic association, occurs when the mites crawl into the nostrils (openings of the nasal cavity) of hummingbirds while they are consuming nectar from a specific plant (Oconnor et al. 1997). It is believed that hummingbirds receive no benefit or harm whereas the mite receives free transportation, and for this reason the transportation relationships qualifies as commensalism. On the other hand, both hummingbird mites and hummingbirds feed on nectar; therefore, they do compete for food resources (Lara and Ornelas, 2002).

Hummingbird flower mites depend on only one or a few host plant species. Individual hummingbirds will sometimes carry mites of more than one species, but there is no mixing of species on individual host plants (Colwell 1983, Heyneman et al. 1991). In the few rare cases where “host-sharing” does occur, the pair of mite species involved are noncongeners; one is a species of Rhinoseius and the other one is a species of Protolaelaps (Colwell, 1973; Heyneman et al. 1991). Hummingbird mites are considered to be very faithful to their different host plant species (Heyneman et al. 1991). Hummingbird mites are also able to differentiate between potential host species and miteless plant species, disembarking from the hummingbird only at flowers of their own host. A potential host species is a plant that has not been colonized by mites, while miteless plant species are plants that mites do not live on. Apparently, they choose plants based on olfactory information (Colwell 1979). Some plants, seemingly well adapted to host mites have been found without mites. It has been postulated that these plant species may produce repellent, noxious, or toxic substances in their nectar, or may lack nutritional value for the hummingbird mites (Colwell 1979).

The different Rhinoseius species have been found on more than 50 hummingbird species and in the flowers of more than 100 plant species (Colwell, 1985). This genus ranges from northern California to central Chile. They are found from sea level all the way up to 4,500 m in places like Ecuador (Colwell, 1983).

"Floridata: Asclepias curassavica." Floridata: Asclepias curassavica. Floridata, 1 Jan. 2014. Web. 18 Apr. 2014. .
Gargiullo, M.B., Magnuson, B., Kimball, L. A Field Guide to Plants of Costa Rica. 2008. Zona Tropical Publication.
Janzen, D. Costa Rican Natural History. 1983. The University of Chicago Press.
Pinheiro, F., Cozzolino, Salvatore. Epidendrum (Orchidaceae) as a model system for ecological and evolutionary studies in the Neotropics. 2013. Taxon 62: 77-88.
Thomas, Bob. "100 Years Loyola University New Orleans." Mexican Milkweed, Asclepias curassivica. Loyola University, 7 Oct. 2009. Web. 17 Apr. 2014. .
"Tropical Milkweed." Butterfly Garden and Habitat Program. North American Butterfly Association, 1 Jan. 2014. Web. 17 Apr. 2014. .

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Associations
dataObject.dc:description: Both Monarch (Danaus plexippus) and Queen (Danaus gilippus) butterflies (Nypmphalidae: Danainae) lay their eggs on A. curassavica (Asclepiadaceae, sometimes Apocynaceae), though its association with Monarch butterflies has been most extensively studied (Floridata 2013). The caterpillars of these species eat the leaves, and so obtain emetic cardenolides, which they retain into adulthood (Thomas 2009). Many species of butterflies and hummingbirds visit the flower for nectar (NABA 2013). Additionally, this plant is often a host for aphids (Thomas 2009). A curassavica may be involved in a floral mimicry complex with non-rewarding Epidendrum radicans (Orchidaceae) and nectar-rich Lantana camara (Verbenaceae; Janzen 1983). These three plants have the same red and orange combination for flowers, share their general butterfly pollinators, have overlapping geographical ranges, and flower simultaneously. They often occur together in their habitats, which may increase pollination success for all three flowers (Pinheiro 2013).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: A. curassavica is native to South America, but is planted all over the world, and has been naturalized in both Old and New World tropical and subtropical areas. It is invasive in the Galapagos and other Pacific Islands (Gargiullo et al 2008). It is found from sea level to 2000 meters altitude (Janzen 1983)

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: Habitat varies from very open areas with full sun to partial sun. It can also occur in soils that are very wet to soils that are somewhat dry (Missouri Botanical Gardens website, 2014). It is found in disturbed habitats, including pastures and road edges (Janzen 1983)

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObject.dc:description: A. curassavica usually blooms from June to October, and is considered a perennial. (Missouri Botanical Garden website, 2014).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObject.dc:description:
A. curassavica is a shrub that grows to about 1 m tall (CABI 2014). The leaves are pointed on both ends, oppositely arranged, and about 12.7 cm long (Floridata 2012). When it blooms, the flowers are perfect, bright red or orange with a yellow center. They occur in an inflorescence, in particular an umbel 5-10 cm wide, on the terminal peduncle, with 7-10 flowers per inflorescence (CABI 2014; Janzen 1983). Each flower has two ovaries with many ovules (Janzen 1983). They are perfect flowers, with five petals which are fused at the base to form a corolla (CABI 2014). The flowers have nectar concentrations from 8% to 24% sugar (Janzen 1983). They are surrounded by five dark green sepals.

The fruit they produce is a pair of dry, dehiscent, light green pods that are 7-10 cm long (Floridata 2012). When they are mature they split open to release seeds that are attached to thin white hairs (CABI 2014). There may be more than one pod grown per influorescence. The pods typically have between 50 and 100 seeds per pod (Janzen 1983).

As a member of the milkweed family, A. curassavica contains a thick, milky latex. This latex is toxic upon ingestion, as it contains cardiac glycosides (Thomas 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description: Like most milkweeds, A. curassavica is pollinated by butterflies. In this case Monarch butterflies are an important pollinator, though it is pollinated by other butterflies as well (Thomas 2009). Each flower contains a pair of pollinia that contain a clump of pollen that the pollinator picks up with its leg or proboscis (Janzen 1983) It is wind dispersed, as the seeds are attached to small, hair-like threads. (Thomas 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description: This plant has been used for contraceptives and to treat snakebites by Native Americans. In addition, it is used as many things in the Tropics including an emetic, laxative, febrifuge, expectorant and to remove warts. It has also been used to treat skin parasites, constipation, venereal disease, kidney stones, and asthma. In Jamaica A. curassavica is used to treat dysentery, and in Indonesia it is used for pneumonia, mastitis, pyoderma, and inflammation of the spleen. (CABI 2014)

taxon.reference: Borgella, R., Snow, A. A. and Gavin, T. A. (2001), Species Richness and Pollen Loads of Hummingbirds Using Forest Fragments in Southern Costa Rica. Biotropica, 33: 90–109.
Garrigues, Richard, and Robert Dean. The birds of Costa Rica: a field guide. Ithaca, N.Y.: Comstock Pub., 2007. Print.
Kroodsma, Donald E.. Ecology and evolution of acoustic communication in birds. Ithaca, N.Y.: Comstock Pub., 1996. Print.
Bird Life International 2012. Purple-throated Mountain-gem Lampornis calolaemus. , n.d. Web. . . Accessed May 2014.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Lampornis calolaemus, formally known as Lampornis calolaema, is a medium sized hummingbird that occurs in the montane cloud forests of Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama (Stiles and Skutch 1989, Garrigues and Dean 2007). These are solitary, aggressive, dominant, and actively defend territories of flowering epiphytes or understory shrubs (Stiles and Skutch 1989). This species is not currently listed as vulnerable and is not of high concern for conservation (Bird Life International 2012).

They are sexually dimorphic. Males have a mostly bronze-green plumage with a brilliant green crown, purple throat, and dark gray tail. They also have a bright metallic green breast. Females lack the bright crown and throat but have rich cinnamon under parts. Juveniles of this species resemble the females but have a distinct crown of feathers on their heads (Stiles and Skutch 1989, Garrigues and Dean 2007).

These hummingbirds feed primarily on nectar from flowers of epiphytic Ericaceae and Gesneriaceae and understory shrubs; however, they will occasionally supplement their diets with the occasional insect prey as other hummingbird species do (Snow 1977, Stiles and Skutch 1989). They have been observed feeding from plants of many different colors have been known to carry the pollen of up to 15 plant species at a time (Snow 1977, Borgella et al. 2001).

taxon.reference: Gargiullo, M. B., B. L. Magnuson, and L. D. Kimball. 2008. A Field Guide to Plants of Costa Rica. Oxford: Oxford USA.
Nadkarni, N., and N. T. Wheelwright. 2000. Monteverde: Ecology and Conservation of a Tropical Cloud Forest. New York: Oxford USA.
Zuchowski, Willow, Turid Forsyth, and Willow Zuchowski. 2007. Tropical Plants of Costa Rica: A Guide to Native and Exotic Flora. Ithaca, NY: Cornell USA.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Aphelandra scabra (Acanthaceae) is a shrub species that ranges from Southern Mexico to Northern South America and the West Indies (Zuchowski 2007). It is found mainly in seasonally dry forests along the Northern Pacific slope up to 1750 m but it can also be found in some moist to wet forests (Gargiullo 2008). A. scabra is normally around 2 m tall but it can grow up to 4 m in height (Zuchowski 2007). The leaves are simple, oppositely arranged on the stalk, and they are elliptical and entire with smooth or wavy margins. The blades can grow up to 25 cm in length, 8 cm in width and the edges of the blades continue down the leaf stems (Gargiullo 2008).

The species may flower and fruit in the wet or dry season (Zuchowski 2007). The flowers of this plant can be red, pink, or purple red, up to 3 cm long, and tubular (garg). They are 2-lipped, fuzzy and they bloom for one day before wilting (Zuchowski 2007). The A. scabra inflorescence is candle-like and the prepubescent flower spikes can grow up to 15 cm in height (Zuchowski 2007). The inflorescence has overlapping green bracts that are tinged with yellow and orange and they have extrafloral nectaries (Zuchowski 2007). Each day only one or two flowers open along the inflorescence to prevent self-pollination (Gavin et al 2011). The flowers have four fertile stamens and a slender stigma that is tucked into the upper lip of the flower (Zuchowski 2007). The flowers are hummingbird pollinated and the species protects its nectar behind a petal lip. When a visiting hummingbird arrives to feed on the nectar, the petal lip releases pollen down onto the head of the bird and it is carried away to pollinate another plant (Gavin et al 2011).

The seed capsules are club-shaped, 2 cm long capsules, and they contain four dark brown seeds (Zuchowski 2007). The seeds are flattened and irregular (Gargiullo 2008) and they are dispersed ballistically, meaning they “explode” (Nadkarni 2000). The fruit seed capsule splits along the sutures, which allow the fruit wall to change its shape rapidly and throw the seeds short distances (Nadkarni 2000).

taxon.reference: Gentry, A. 1993. A Field Guide to the Families and Genera of Woody Plants of Northwest South America. The University of Chicago Press. pp. 102-103.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description:
Xanthosoma robustum, commonly called elephant ear, is a terrestrial Araceae plant. It can be 1-4 meters long and 10-20cm thick. X. robustum is characterized by having up to four palmately dissected or triangular succulent leaves (1 meter in length and width). It possesses strong basal lobes, reticulate venation, and typically one can see both marginal and sub-marginal collecting veins on the leaves (Gentry 1993). The inflorescence consists of the spathe and spadix – male flowers on top of the spadix are separated from female flowers by a sterile ring of flowers. Female flowers are found within the lower part of the spathe, creating a chamber-like kettle. Flowering takes place primarily during the rainy season. The plant can produce 5-15 inflorescences annually, roughly nine days apart (Goldwasser 2000).

The native range of this plant is from Mexico to Costa Rica. X. robustum can be found in thickets or thin forest, 1800 meters or lower. The plant thrives in marshy, wet soil near streams (Standley et. al. 1958). In Monteverde this plant species is considered a weed.

X. robustum is pollinated by two species of scarab beetles within the genus Cyclocephela. On day one, the inflorescence opens and the spadix heats up (called a thermogenic spadix), peaking around 40-42 degrees Celsius. This process causes the emission of a sweet odor that attracts scarab beetles toward the spathe and into the kettle. The spathe cools, constricts, and encloses the beetles within the kettle for 24 hours where they consume the sterile flowers and mate. By the second afternoon, the inflorescence heats up again to around 34 degrees Celsius and the male flowers release pollen. The scarab beetles crawl out of the kettle covered in pollen, and fly to another inflorescence where this process repeats. The top of the inflorescence rots and falls off of the plant in the following days, while the bottom of the inflorescence takes around two months to mature. The spathe will split open when the fruit is ripe and a cob-like fruit will be present. Each fruit contains 20-30 seeds and are consumed/dispersed by bats (Goldwasser 2000).

In aroids, heating is initiated by light and once the process begins, it does not stop until it runs its full course. Scarab beetles that pollinate X. robustum may visit other aroids, reducing pollination efficiency. Economically, X. robustum is an important “indigenous medicinal, fiber (from roots), and arrow-poison” plant and is poisonous if consumed (Simpson 2006).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#ConservationStatus
dataObject.dc:description: Not threatened ("Pentaclethra macroloba," 2005).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Description
dataObject.dc:description: P. macroloba is a Neotropical canopy and subcanopy tree with a maximum height of 40 m and d.b.h of 130 cm. It has a fluted base and modest buttresses. The base can be relatively open, especially for trees in swampy areas, suggesting seedling establishment on a nurse log that since decomposed. The leaves of P. macroloba are shiny, bipinnately compound, alternate, stipuled, and without glands (Flores 2002, Hartshorn 1983). Leaves can be up to 30 cm long, and their numerous tiny leaflets (about 2 x 10 mm) give them a feather-like appearance (Hartshorn 1983, Jøker & Salazar 2000). The bark is smooth and white to grayish-brown with horizontal lenticels, and the wood on the inside is pinkish to dark red (Flores 2002, Hartshorn 1983). The wood is very resistant to decomposition, with logs on the forest floor enduring for 10-20 years (Hartshorn 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObject.dc:description: P. macroloba has three disjunct Neotropical populations. The largest population ranges from northeastern Venezuela (including Trinidad and Tobago), through the Atlantic lowlands of the Guianas and into the eastern Amazon basin in Brazil. A second population occurs in Chocó Department in western Colombia and the adjacent province of Darién in western Panama. A third population occupies the Atlantic lowlands of southeastern Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and western Panama (Hartshorn 1983). P. macroloba is also native to Cuba and Jamaica (Orwa et al. 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Ecology
dataObject.dc:description: P. macroloba exhibits different characteristics among its disjunct American populations. In the Venezuelan-Guianan-Brazilian population, P. macroloba is a medium-sized subcanopy tree present in medium densities on sedimentary river terraces. In the Colombain-Panamanian population, P. macroloba is a subcanopy tree of up to 65 cm d.b.h. present in low densities. Trees in the Central American population can be the dominant canopy species and grow to 40 m tall and 130 cm d.b.h. (Hartshorn 1983). In the canopy of La Selva, Costa Rica, P. macroloba is the dominant species, with importance values [IV = (% density + % frequency + % basal area)/3] of 19-23%, more than twice those of the second most important species (Hartshorn 1983). The success of P. macroloba likely rests on a combination of factors: (1) successful seedling establishment due to seed toxicity and an overall absence of seed predators, (2) competitive superiority in infertile soils, (3) competitive superiority in swampy conditions, and (4) shade tolerance that allows recruits to be successful in the dense understory (Hartshorn 1983). Nodules of N-fixing bacteria attached to adventitious roots in P. macroloba may allow the trees to survive in swampy conditions (Walter & Bien 1989). Furthermore, P. macroloba’s increased growth in the dry season (December-April) may give it a competitive advantage over its fellow common trees Goelthalsia (Tiliaceae) and Carapa (Meliaceae), which show decreased growth in the dry season (Hazlett 1987). P. macroloba's slow growth inhibits it from forming a pure stand at La Selva, where the rapid forest turnover rate allows other, faster-growing canopy species to colonize gaps (Hartshorn 1983).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObject.dc:description: P. macroloba is common in swampy lowland tropical forests up to 600 m where rainfall is more than 3500 mm annually and temperatures range from 24-30°C (Flores 2002, Jøker & Salazar 2000).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObject.dc:description:
P. macroloba flowers at a relatively early age, with trees in open, well-lit areas first flowering at approximately 2 years. The tree flowers throughout the wet season (May-November) with peaks in April-May and July-August (Jøker & Salazar 2000). The flowers are brushlike terminal inflorescences approximately 15 cm long with purple calyces and distinct white staminoids. Although the flowers receive many insect visitors, their true pollinator is unknown (Hartshorn 1983).

Of the approximately 200 flowers on an inflorescence, only 0-5 will develop fruits. P. macroloba fruits are dark brown legumes 20-50 cm long and 4-6 cm wide. There are 3-8 seeds per pod. Seeds are 2 cm wide and 4 cm long, have a brown seed coat, and lack endosperm. The dehiscent pods turn gray as they dry out, suddenly opening and launching seeds 10 m or more (Hartshorn 1983, Jøker & Salazar 2000). Due to the seeds’ toxic levels of alkaloids and amino acids, seed predation is generally regarded as low, although the spiny pocket mouse (Heteromys desmarestianus) is able to eat a small number of seeds (Anhalzer et al. 2009, Hartshorn 1983). At La Selva, Costa Rica, pre-dispersal seed predation by the white-crowned parrot (Pionus senilis) and gray squirrels (Sciurus variegatoides) may occur on up to 5% of seeds (Hartshorn 1972). Anhalzer et al. (2010) found some level of predation on 22% of P. macroloba legumes and suggest that legume damage may significantly compromise elastic dispersal capability. Recent research also suggests the larvae of the Lepidopteran Carmenta surinamensis may in fact be significant seed predators (McKenna & McKenna 2006).

The seeds will germinate regardless of light conditions. High germination success, coupled with low seed predation, leads to a notable abundance of seeds and seedlings on the forest floor (Jøker & Salazar 2000, Hartshorn 1983). P. macroloba seedlings were found to experience high levels of herbivory at Tirimbina, Costa Rica (Dyer et al. 2010).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObject.dc:description:
The seeds of P. macroloba are composed of 45-48% lipid, 27-28% protein, and 12-14% carbohydrates (Orwa et al. 2009). The oil can be extracted and used for candle and soap production (Arkcoll 1984). It is widely used as a cooking oil in Africa (Orwa et al. 2009). Additionally, the seeds can be ground and fed to livestock (Arkcoll 1984).

The wood is hard, heavy, strong, easy to work, and resistant to deterioration, with a specific gravity of 750-850 kg/m3. Its wood is attractive but not distinctive and is often used as a substitute for mahogany. P. macroloba wood can be used in railroad ties, construction, house frames, and flooring (Orwa et al. 2009).

P. macroloba has several medicinal uses. Extracts from the seeds and bark can be used for snakebites, ulcers, insect bites, and dysentary (Orwa et al. 2009).

As a nitrogen-fixing pioneer species, P. macroloba has important potential uses in forest regeneration and the reclamation of disturbed land. In secondary-growth rainforests in the Caribbean lowlands of Costa Rica, P. macroloba likely plays a pivotal role in the recovery of soil fertility; soil carbon, phosphorous, and nitrogen; soil microbial and fungal communities; and above-ground plant species diversity. In contrast, in primary forests of the area, P. macroloba plays less of a dominant role. There, P. macroloba and Inga spp. (Fabaceae) are part of a community of leguminous plants that enhances soil nutrient quantity and quality (Shebitz & Eaton 2013). P. macroloba has been used to rehabilitate degraded savannah in Africa, as well as in firebreaks in the Congo (Orwa et al. 2009).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Psychotria carthagenensis is a shrub of the Rubiaceae family found in moist to seasonally dry forests from Mexico to Argentina and Brazil (Gargiullo et al. 2008). P. carthagenensis grows to 0.3 – 3 m tall in the understory in forests typically from sea level to 200 m, although it can be found up to 1400 m (Fern 2012). It has slender stems with dark bark and conspicuous stipule scars (Gargiullo et al. 2008). Leaves are arranged oppositely with interpetiolar stipules (Silva Moraes et al. 2011). Stipules have multicellular tricomes called colleters which secrete a gummy substance (Lersten 1974). Leaves have a pointed tip and show pinnate venation with short 1 cm petioles and 6 – 13 cm blades (Gargiullo et al. 2008). P. carthagenensis can be distinguished by its convex petiole (Silva Moraes et al. 2011). The flower is small, white, and tubular shaped on 3 – 8 cm branched inflorescences with an inferior ovary, blooming between February and July (Gargiullo et al. 2008). P. carthagenensis has distyly flowers, meaning there is a long-styled morph and a short-styled morph (Faria et al. 2011). Flowers are pollinated by bees and butterflies which are rewarded with nectar (Faria and Lima 2008). P. carthagenensis produces red to orange fleshy drupes containing two seeds each which are bird dispersed (Gargiullo et al. 2008; Paul et al. 2009).

P. carthagenensis is deciduous, shade tolerant, slow growing, and tolerant to many soil types (Fern 2012). The species prefers wet soils and is commonly found in areas which are naturally disturbed by flooding (Faria and Lima 2008) In secondary forests P. carthagenensis may be the most abundant shrub in the understory (Aragon and Morales 2003). Some individuals benefit from the protection of ants from the genus Crematogaster who protect the plant from herbivory (Faria and Lima 2008). In the absence of these ants inflorescences are inhabited by spiders which feed on both herbivores and pollinators (Faria and Lima 2008).

P. carthagenensis has been utilized throughout the Amazon as an ingredient in the psychoactive beverage ayahuasca (Lea and Elisabetsky 1996). The leaves contain bioactive compounds which have strong opiate-like effects of sedation and decreased body temperature, although the structure of these compounds is not known (Leal and Elisabetsky 1996). These compounds are likely made as a deterrent to herbivory as the leaves are toxic to grazing cattle (Leal and Elisabesky 1996). The shrub is sometimes harvested for its wood (Fern 2012).

taxon.reference: Mishra, S. 2005. Morphology of Fungi. Discovery Publishing House: Darya Ganj, India.

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObject.dc:description:
Leccinum monticola is a recently described species in Costa Rica (Halling and Muller 2003). The entire Leccinum genus is characterized by the formation of ectomycorrhizal associations with host trees (Bakker et al. 2004). Typically species have been described as host specialists, only forming associations with a single tree species. L. monticola has been observed in association with Comarostaphylis arbutoides—a tree in the Ericaceae family (Halling and Muller 2003). This is unique among North American Leccinum species as most have been associated with trees in the Betulaceae family (Halling and Muller 2003). Individuals of L. monticola have been detected at 3491m in the bamboo paramo of Cerro de la Muerte, and were also previously found between 2800 and 3000m in the Cordillera Talamanca (Halling and Muller 2003). Members of the Leccinum genus have been described as edible (if properly handled, stored and cooked) (Mishra 2005), and Halling and Muller describe the taste and odor of L. monticola as mild (Halling and Muller 2003).

Leccinum species have been described generally as having large, tough fruiting bodies with a dry leathery cap (Stephenson 2010). Halling and Muller (2003) have indicated that the pileus of L. monticola specimens can exhibit a range in breadth between 5.5-15cm, which is initially obtusely convex (Halling and Muller 2003). However, with time, the pileus becomes plano-convex, and can change in color from an intital brownish orange disc pattern, to rings of brown, to an even brown color, then to an even brownish orange color, and finally to a light brown tint (Halling and Muller 2003). Like other species in the Leccinum genus, L. monticola exhibits a flap of sterile tissue at the brim of the pileus (Halling and Muller 2003). In L. monticola, the color pattern of this margin matches that of the pilleus (Halling and Muller 2003). Furthermore, the surface of specimens have been described with varying degrees of hair-like extensions and the flesh of this species is usually white and between 15-30 cm thick (Halling and Muller 2003). The pilleus pellis is trichoderm with the flesh staining fuscous to pink.

The hymenophore of L. monticola is tubular with gills that are free to adnexed (Halling and Muller 2003). Tubes have a pale yellow color and are between 10-30cm long with 2-3mm wide pores, but upon injury, color changes to a bronze yellow or brown when bruised (Halling and Muller 2003). The stipe are club-shaped, white (becoming pale grey with age), and scabbed (scabs are also white when young, but become black to brown with age) (Halling and Muller 2003). Basidia are club-shaped and Halling and Muller describe the basidiospores as umber to olive brown (Halling and Muller 2003).

dataObject.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#TaxonBiology
dataObject.dc:description: Elvira cupreiceps, or the Coppery-Headed Emerald, is a small hummingbird endemic to Costa Rica. This species typically measures about 7.5cm in length and weighs an average of 3.2g (Stiles & Skutch 1989). The male is a bronze-green color with a copper color to the crown of the head and bright metallic yellow-green underparts. The female is a metallic green with gray-white underparts. Both have four pairs of white outer retrices; however, in the male the outermost pair is tipped with black and the other three with gray, while in the female the outermost pair is tipped with black or gray and all have a V-shaped subterminal bar of gray. Both have a bronze central pair of retrices. Both have purplish-brown remiges with bronze-green inner secondaries. The bill is slightly curved and black with a pinkish color from the base to the mandible. The young are a duller bronze-green color, and young females have cinnamon-colored feather-edgings (Schulenberg & Sedgwick 2013; Stiles & Skutch 1989). The Coppery-Headed Emerald resides in wet montane forest or nearby in gaps, at forest edges, and in other semiopen areas. Males can be found in the forest canopy, while females are generally found in the understory (Stiles & Skutch 1989). This species feeds on nectar from trees such as Pithecellobium, Quararibea, and Guarea; epiphytes such as Ericaceae and Clusia; Besleria understory shrubs; Stachytarpheta and Inga shrubs in new growth forest (Feinsinger 1977); as well as feeding on small arthropods (Stiles 1999). This species is generally solitary (Schulenberg & Sedgwick 2013). Little is known about this species' mating behavior, but it is presumed to be polygynous as are most hummingbird species (Schuchmann 1999). Breeding takes place between October and March. A small nest is made in a shrub or treefern 1-3m off the ground in the forest understory. Males form aggregations (called leks) to attrack females. These lekes involve singing at and chasing one another (Stiles & Skutch 1989). Though its range is very small, this species is considered "Least Concern" by IUCN Red List (BirdLife International 2013).
